   Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies

   utilization / Plant microhabitat utilization / Plant associates] [Forest
   and woodland /  / biology; distribution; faunal list] [Cuba / La Isabela
   / ].

TI ADDITION TO THE RECLASSIFICATION OF BRACHYURAN CRABS (CRUSTACEA:
   DECAPODA: BRACHYURA) PART I. NEW TAXA.
AU Stevcic, Zdravko
SO Natura Croatica
VL 20
IS 1
PS 125-139
PD June 30 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In the continuation of the revision of the brachyuran system some
   additions are given. A good number of new higher taxa are established:
   families, subfamilies, tribes and genera. New taxa are briefly
   diagnosed, named and their systematic position is indicated.

TI ENDOGEAN AND CAVERNICOLOUS COLEOPTERA OF THE BALKANS. XI. REVISION OF

   (COLEOPTERA: CURCULIONIDAE: ENTIMINAE).

PS 189-200
PD June 30 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The subgenus Troglorhynchus Reitter, 1854 of the genus Otiorhynchus
   Germar, 1824 is redescribed, revised and differentiated from other
   subgenera of Otiorhynchus, which has the micro or anophthalmus species.
   T. anophthalmoides omeros Colonnelli, 2003, T. pretneri F. Solari, 1955
   as well as T. celejensis G. Muller, 1924 are synonymized to T.
   anophthalmoides Reitter, 1914.

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Closer examination of material of Macrorrhyncha rostrata Zetterstedt,
   1851 from Sweden revealed a mixture of two closely related species of
   which one, M. hugoi sp. n. is described based on type material from
   Southern Sweden, Southern England and the Channel Islands. The new
   species includes all known records of M. rostrata from England and the
   Channel Islands. Records of M, rostrata from continental Europe need to
   be verified.

PM 21349643
DT Article
TI Helminth parasites in faecal samples from the endangered Iberian lynx
   (Lynx pardinus).
AU Acosta, L.
   Leon-Quinto, T.
   Bornay-Llinares, F.J. (f.bornay@umh.es) 
   Simon, M.A.
   Esteban, J.G.
SO Veterinary Parasitology
VL 179
IS 1-3
PS 175-179
PD Jun 30 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB The Iberian lynx is the most endangered felid in the world.
   Enteropathogens may threaten its survival, and therefore we analysed
   faecal samples from 66 different individuals (37 males and 29 females),
   the largest population representation studied to date. The samples were
   obtained from November 2005 to October 2008 in the two areas where the
   Iberian lynx survives: Sierra Morena and Donana (Andalusia, southern
   Spain). A total of 56.1% samples were parasitized with at least 6
   species of helminths, including two cestodes (Hymenolepis spp. and
   Taenia spp.) and four Nematodes (Ancylostoma spp., Toxocara spp.,
   Toxascaris leonina, and Capillaria sp.). In this work, the presence of
   Hymenolepis is reported for the first time in Lynx pardinus. The
   relevance of our findings is discussed focussed on the conservation of
   this endangered fetid. [copyright] 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Bornay-Llinares, F.J.; Univ Miguel Hernandez Elche, Dept Agroquim &
   Medio Ambiente, Ctra Valencia Km 8-7, Alicante, Spain, Spain.
EM f.bornay@umh.es
OI Acosta Soto, Lucrecia/0000-0003-3989-0218
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0304-4017
BD Conservation; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth
   parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Ancylostoma; Capillariinae; Taenia; Toxascaris leonina; Toxocara
   [Mammalian hosts / Lynx pardinus / Prevalence] [Spain / Andalucia,
   Sierra Morena & Donana / ]. 
   Hymenolepis [Mammalian hosts / Lynx pardinus / New record; prevalence]
   [Spain / Donana National Park / ]. 
   Lynx pardinus [Conservation /  / prevalence] [Cestode parasites /
   Hymenolepis / New record] [ / Taenia / ] [Nematode parasites /
   Ancylostoma / ] [ / Toxascaris leonina / ] [ / Toxocara / ] [ /
   Capillariinae / ] [Spain / Andalucia, Sierra Morena & Donana / ] [ /
   Donana National Park / ]. 
TN Carnivores; Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes;
   Platyhelminths; Vertebrates

   Platyhelminthes, Cestoda

AN ZOOR14709064570
DT Article
TI A new highland species of Pristimantis Jimenez de la Espada, 1871
   (Anura: Strabomantidae) from the Pantepui region, northern South
   America.
AU Kok, Philippe J.R. (Philippe.Kok@vub.ac.be) 
   Means, D. Bruce
   Bossuyt, Franky
SO Zootaxa
VL 2934
PS 1-19
PD 30 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2934.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02934p019.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new strabomantid frog of the genus Pristimantis Jimenez de la Espada,
   1871 is described from the Eastern Pantepui Region, Guiana Shield,
   northern South America. The new species, Pristimantis aureoventris sp.
   nov., is known so far from two neighbouring tepuis, namely Wei Assipu
   Tepui (type locality) at the border between Guyana and Brazil and Mount
   Roraima in Guyana, and occurs between 2210[long dash]2305 m elevation.
   The new taxon is distinguished from all known congeners by the following
   combination of characters: Finger I < II; tympanum distinct; basal
   webbing between Toes IVV; broad lateral fringes on fingers and toes;
   ventral skin areolate; vocal slits absent in male; two non-spinous
   whitish nuptial pads and vocal sac present in male; high degree of
   pattern polymorphism; throat, chest, and belly golden yellow, usually
   with reddish brown to dark brown mottling; internal organs little or not
   visible through the ventral skin in life. The call of the new species
   consists of bouts of a single amplitude-modulated (decreasing to the
   end) note repeated at a rate of ca. 18 notes/min with a dominant
   frequency ranging from 2180 to 2430 Hz.
C1 Kok, Philippe J.R.; Biology Department, Unit of Ecology and Systematics,
   Vrije Universiteit Brussel, 2 Pleinlaan, B-1050 Brussels, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM Philippe.Kok@vub.ac.be
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Pristimantis aureoventris [Guyana /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Leptodactylidae
OR Pristimantis aureoventris (Leptodactylidae): [Sp nov, Guyana, P. 4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709064570
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14709064571
DT Article
TI A new species of Petrocephalus Marcusen 1854 (Osteoglossomorpha:
   Mormyridae) from the Sanaga River basin, Cameroon.
AU Lavoue, Sebastien (microceb@hotmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2934
PS 20-28
PD 30 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2934.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02934p028.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Petrocephalus similis n. sp. is described from the Djerem River, upper
   Sanaga basin, in Cameroon. It can be distinguished from all other
   Petrocephalus from West and Central Africa by an unique combination of
   morphological characters including: body without melanin mark, 22[long
   dash]24 branched rays in the dorsal fin and 28 or 29 branched rays in
   the anal fin, mouth commissure under the posterior half of the eye.
   Petrocephalus similis mostly resembles Petrocephalus sullivani. Yet, P.
   similis has proportionally a larger mouth and a wider head, and reaches
   a longer maximum standard length. The electric organ discharge waveform
   of this species is not known. Molecular comparisons based on cytochrome
   b nucleotide sequences are congruent with morphological comparisons in
   independently supporting the distinctiveness of this species from 17
   other species of Petrocephalus. Within the genus Petrocephalus, P.
   similis belongs to a group that is almost exclusively composed of
   endemic species of Central Africa, pointing out its likely origin from
   this region. Additional examinations of museum specimens from the Sanaga
   River basin demonstrate the occurrence of at least two other species of
   Petrocephalus: Petrocephalus microphthalmus, and a second species which
   is conservatively assigned to Petrocephalus cf. christyi, pending
   additional evidence.
C1 Lavoue, Sebastien; Institute of Oceanography, National Taiwan
   University, Roosevelt Road, Taipei 10617, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM microceb@hotmail.com
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution;
   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Petrocephalus [Cytochromes / Cytochrome b gene sequences / ] [Molecular
   genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Africa /  / ]. 
   Petrocephalus similis [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Osteoglossiformes, Mormyridae
OR Petrocephalus (Mormyridae). 
   Petrocephalus similis (Mormyridae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 23].

DA 2020-09-17

TI A new characid fish, Moenkhausia aurantia (Ostariophysi: Characiformes:
   Characidae), from the upper rio Tocantins basin in Central Brazil.
AU Bertaco, Vinicius A. (vbertaco@gmail.com) 
   Jerep, Fernando C.
   Carvalho, Fernando R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2934
PS 29-38
PD 30 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2934.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02934p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new characid species, Moenkhausia aurantia, is described from the
   upper portions of rio Tocantins basin, in the Chapada dos Veadeiros,
   Goias State, central Brazil. The new species differs from its congeners
   by the combination of 3 or 4 scale rows below and 5 or 6 scale rows
   above the lateral line, 21[long dash]25 branched anal-fin rays, 33[long
   dash]35 lateral line scales, 2[long dash]4 maxillary teeth, one diffuse
   humeral spot, and caudal spot continuous to the longitudinal line which
   extends posteriorly over the middle caudal-fin rays. A key to identify
   Moenkhausia species describe from the Tocantins-Araguaia basin is
   provided.
C1 Bertaco, Vinicius A.; Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul,
   Instituto de Biociencias, Departamento de Zoologia, Laboratorio de
   Ictiologia, Av. Bento Goncalves, 9500, 91501-970 Porto Alegre, RS,
   Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI A new Clymenura (Polychaeta: Maldanidae) from the intertidal of Banks
   Peninsula, New Zealand, with a reassessment of Leiochone Grube, 1868 and
   Clymenura Verrill, 1900.
AU Read, Geoffrey B. (g.read@niwa.co.nz) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2934
PS 39-52
PD 30 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2934.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02934p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A maldanid discovered on sand beaches of Banks Peninsula, South Island,
   New Zealand is newly described. Clymenura snaiko sp. nov. is of large
   size at over 250 mm length, with 18 chaetigers, two achaetous preanal
   segments with tori, unmodified dentate uncini in anterior chaetigers, a
   ventral glandular shield on chaetiger eight, a high cephalic rim notched
   laterally, and a deep anal funnel rimmed with 16 short subequal cirri
   and one longer ventral cirrus. The confused taxonomy of
   ventral-shield-bearing maldanids is reassessed and clarified. Leiochone
   Grube 1868 and Clymenura Verrill, 1900 are here treated as the valid
   members of Arwidsson's (1906) tribe Leiochonini in Euclymeninae, and
   given emended diagnoses, while Imajima and Shiraki's (1982) subfamily
   Clymenurinae and Clymenura subgenus Cly. (Cephalata) are considered
   invalid. Differentiating character states of the valid Leiochonini
   species are tabulated. Leiochone is restricted to six species, including
   the new combinations L. annulata (Mohammad, 1980) and L. japonica
   (Imajima & Shiraki, 1982). Clymenura is restricted to nine valid taxa,
   including Cly. snaiko sp. nov. and the new combination Cly. polaris lena
   (Averincev, 1990). These updated groupings exclude a further eight
   nominal taxa which mostly may be indeterminable. Leiochone species occur
   in inshore temperate to tropical Eastern Hemisphere waters, while
   Clymenura mostly occur in high North European latitudes and the northern
   Pacific region, usually offshore in deep water. The new species is the
   first record of a Clymenura from Southern Hemisphere waters, and the
   second member of the genus to be found in the intertidal.
C1 Read, Geoffrey B.; National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research
   Limited (NIWA), Private Bag 14 901, Kilbirnie, Wellington, New Zealand,
   New Zealand.
EM g.read@niwa.co.nz
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Clymenura [Marine zones / Southern Hemisphere / New record]. 
   Clymenura snaiko [South Pacific / New Zealand / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Clymene ebiensis - Milne Edwards 1843 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P.
   41]. 
   Clymene leiopygos - Grube 1860 (Polychaeta): [Designated type species
   for, Leiochone Grube 1868, p. 40]. 
   Clymene urceolata - Leidy 1855 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P. 41]. 
   Clymenura - Verrill 1900 (Polychaeta): [Emended diagnosis, P. 44; Syn
   nov, Clymenura (Cephalata) Imajima & Shiraki 1982, p. 46; New record]. 
   Clymenura annulata - Imajima & Shiraki 1982 (Polychaeta): [Referred to,
   Leiochone, p. 41]. 
   Clymenura annulata - Mohammad 1980 (Polychaeta): [Referred to,
   Leiochone, p. 41]. 
   Clymenura gracilis - Hartman 1969 (Polychaeta): [Taxonomic position,
   Incertae sedis, p. 45]. 
   Clymenura polaris lena - (Averincev 1990) (Polychaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Leiochone, p. 45]. 
   Clymenura snaiko (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, New Zealand (marine), P. 46]. 
   Clymenurinae - Imajima & Shiraki 1982 (Polychaeta): [Status, P. 40]. 
   Leiocephalus parvus - Quatrefages 1866 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P.
   41]. 
   Leiochone - Grube 1868 (Polychaeta): [Type species, Designated, Clymene
   leiopygos Grube 1860, p. 40; Emended diagnosis, P. 40]. 
   Leiochone annulata - (Mohammad 1980) (Polychaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Clymenura, p. 41]. 
   Leiochone japonica - (Imajima & Shiraki 1982) (Polychaeta): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Clymenura, p. 41]. 
   Leiochone polaris acirrata - Zachs 1923 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P.
   41]. 
   Leiochone polaris lena - Averincev 1990 (Polychaeta): [Referred to,
   Clymenura, p. 45]. 
   Leiochone singularis - Gravier 1907 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P. 41].
   
   Leiochone tropica - Mesnil & Fauvel 1939 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P.
   41]. 
   Praxilla simplex - Claparede 1870 (Polychaeta): [Nomen dubium, P. 41]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709064575
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14709064579
DT Article
TI A new genus for Psopheticus megalops Takeda, 1989 (Crustacea: Brachyura:
   Goneplacidae).
AU Ng, Peter K.L. (dbsngkl@nus.edu.sg) 
   Komai, Tomoyuki
SO Zootaxa
VL 2934
PS 61-67
PD 30 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2934.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02934p067.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus is established for Psopheticus megalops Takeda, 1989, an
   unusual and poorly known species of goneplacoid crab known only from
   Japan. The carapace and male gonopods are very distinctive, and easily
   distinguish it from all other genera. Although its classification in the
   Goneplacidae has been questioned, its thoracic sternal and other
   characters clearly argue for its continued retention in this family.
C1 Ng, Peter K.L.; Tropical Marine Science Institute, Kent Ridge Campus,
   National University of Singapore, Upper Kent Ridge Road, Singapore,
   Singapore.
EM dbsngkl@nus.edu.sg
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Pedroplax (Brachyura): [Gen nov, Of family Goneplacidae, Type species
   Psopheticus megalops Takeda 1989, p. 61].

DT Article
TI New species and new records of click beetles from the Palearctic region
   (Coleoptera, Elateridae).
AU Platia, Giuseppe (pinoplatia-@teletu.it) 
SO Boletin de la SEA
VL 48
PS 47-60
PD 30 junio 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Fourteen new species of click beetles belonging to the genera
   Cardiophorus (Turkey), Dicronychus (Syria), Dima (Greece), Hemicrepidius
   (Azerbaijan), Athous (Orthathous) (Azerbaijan), Agriotes (Lebanon),
   Ampedus (Sardinia, Italy), Ctenicera (Slovenia), Anostirus (Azerbaijan),
   Selatosomus (Warchalowskia) (Turkey), Adrastus (Azerbaijan) and
   Melanotus (Lebanon) are described. New chorological data for fifty-one
   species from the Palaearctic region are given.

AN ZOOR14711077825
DT Article
TI [A new species of Italian pliocene: Murexsul plionanum (Gastropoda:
   Muricidae).]
FT Una nuova specie del Pliocene italiano: Murexsul plionanum (Gastropoda:
   Muricidae).
AU Forli, Maurizio (info@dodoline.it) 
   Brunetti, M. Mauro
SO Bollettino Malacologico
VL 47
IS 1
PS 1-8
PD 30 giugno 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new muricid, Murexsul plionanum n. sp, is described from the Early
   Pliocene (Zanclean) of Tuscany (Northern Italy), based on 108 shells
   from four localities near Florence (Villa Filicaia) and Siena (Podere
   Sant'Uliviere, Melograni, Acqua Calda). It is a small sized specie
   (shell height < 14 mm), with a biconical shell outline and a sculpture
   of 6-7 axial ribs on the last teleoconch whorl. The only species
   particularly similar to Murexsul plionanum n. sp. are three Recent
   muricids from the Mediterranean, Murexsul cevikeri (Houart, 2000),
   Ocinebrina erronea (Settepassi, 1977) and Ocinebrina hispidula (Pallary,
   1904).
C1 Forli, Maurizio; Via Grocco 16, Prato, I-59100, Italy, Italy.
EM info@dodoline.it
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0394-7149
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Murexsul plionanum [Italy /  / new species] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Muricoidea

   Fossil].

DT Article
TI The genus Diplocentrus Peters (Scorpiones: Diplocentridae) in Morelos,
   Mexico.
AU Santibanez Lopez, Carlos E. (ironc81@hotmail.com) 
   Francke, Oscar F.
   Cordova Athanasiadis, Milagros
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 19
PS 3-13
PD 30 Junio 2009(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Sixteen scorpion species are recorded from the state of Morelos,
   including three species of the genus Diplocentrus Peters: one species
   had been previously re-ported, a second one represents a new state
   record for the species, and the third one is described as a new species.
   Diplocentrus longimanus sp. n., from the Sierra de Huautla in southern
   Morelos, is described based on adults of both sexes and it is clearly
   differentiated from its most similar relatives. Maps of the known
   distribution of the three species are provided.
C1 Santibanez Lopez, Carlos E.; Coleccion Nacional de Aracnidos,
   Departamento de Zoologia, Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico,
   Apartado Postal 70-153, Mexico DF 04510, Mexico.

PT J
AN ZOOR14707048396
DT Article
TI Spiders associated to Cyrtophora citricola Forsskal, 1775 (Araneae:
   Araneidae) webs in urban and rural areas of the upper Cauca River
   valley, Colombia.
FT Aranas asociadas a redes de Cyrtophora citricola (Forsskal, 1775)
   (Araneae: Araneidae) en zonas urbanas y rurales del valle alto del rio
   Cauca, Colombia.
AU Betancur, Nili J. (nilijota@gmail.com) 
   Cabra-Garcia, Jimmy J.
   Armbrecht, Inge
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 19
PS 15-21
PD 30 Junio 2009(2011)
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB Cyrtophora citricola (Forsskal, 1775) weaves complex webs, which are
   infrequently removed. These webs are attractive to kleptoparasites and
   commensal spiders. This study taxonomically characterized the
   araneofauna associated to webs of C. citricola in urban and rural areas
   of the upper Cauca river valley. Hand collections were made along 8 belt
   transects (100 x 4 m). A total 115 individuals were collected, of which
   35.7% were adults. The adults are grouped into four families, six genera
   and ten species. Faiditus caudatus (Taczanowski, 1874) was the most
   common and abundant species (70.7 % of the total collected). Neighboring
   webs of Nephila clavipes (Linnaeus, 1767) and Leucauge sp. (White) were
   detected. We reported ten spider species associated to Cyrtophora in
   Colombia, distinct from those already known. Faiditus cochleaformus
   (Exline, 1945) is first recorded in the country.
C1 Betancur, Nili J.; Wildlife Conservation Society, WCS, Cali, Colombia,
   Colombia.
EM nilijota@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Associations; Ecology; Animal constructions; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Araneae [Associations / Cyrtophora citricola (Arachnida) / Recorded on
   webs] [Colombia / Upper Cauca River / Arachnid associates]. 
   Cyrtophora citricola [Associations / Araneae (Arachnida) / ] [Webs /  /
   Arachnid associates] [Colombia / Upper Cauca River / ]. 
   Faiditus cochleaformus [Colombia / Upper Cauca River / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Araneae (Arachnida). 
   Cyrtophora citricola (Araneae). 
   Faiditus cochleaformus (Araneae): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14707048396
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AB A new species of melicharid mite, Proctolaelaps izabelae sp. n. was
   found in the nest of European starling Sturnus vulgaris in the
   Netherlands. Female, male and deutonymph of this new species are
   described and illustrated. A short key is provided for the Proctolaelpas
   Berlese associated with the nest of birds.

PT J
AN ZOOR14707048398
DT Article
TI A nature's treasury: pseudoscorpion diversity of the Canary Islands,
   with the description of none new species (Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae,
   Cheiridiidae) and new records.
AU Mahnert, Volker (volker.mahnert@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 19
PS 27-45
PD 30 Junio 2009(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the subgenus Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) from
   Tenerife and Gran Canaria and five new species of the genus
   Lagynochthonius (Chthoniidae) are described from the mesovoid shallow
   substratum (MSS) of Gran Canaria. The presence of four lanceolate setae
   on the movable chelal finger of Lagynochthonius species is a previously
   unrecorded morphological character in this genus. Paraliochthonius
   curvidigitatus (Mahnert) is replaced in its original genus
   Lagynochthonius. Apocheiridium lienhardi sp. nov. (Cheiridiidae) is
   described from the island of El Hierro, the species is characterized by
   the presence of only 6 trichobothria on the fixed chelal finger. The
   subgenus Apocheiridium (Chiliocheiridium) Vitali-di Castri is sunk in
   the synonymy of Apocheiridium J. C. Chamberlin, it was only known from
   three species from Chile. Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) canariensis
   stat. nov. is elevated from subspecies rank; Geogarypus mirei Heurtault
   (Geogarypidae) and Garypus s. saxicola Waterhouse (Garypidae) are
   recorded for the first time from the Canarian Archipelago, several other
   species are added to the fauna of different islands. Identification keys
   are provided to the species of the genera Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius)
   and Lagynochthonius from the Canary Islands.
C1 Mahnert, Volker; Museum d'histoire naturelle, case postale 6434,
   CH-1211, Geneve 6, Switzerland, Switzerland.

   oromii; Lagynochthonius subterraneus; Lagynochthonius tenuimanus [Canary

   Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius); Lagynochthonius [Canary Islands /  / Key
   to species]. 
   Pseudoscorpiones [Canary Islands /  / New record].

DT Article
TI A new genus and four new species of erythraeid mites from Indonesia,
   with new records of the family (Acari: Prostigmata: Erythraeidae).
AU Haitlinger, Ryszard (ryszard.haitlinger@up.wroc.pl) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 19
PS 47-54
PD 30 Junio 2009(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Erythraeus (Zaracarus) bibadakiensis sp.n., Grandjeanella londaensis sp.
   n., Marantelophus alaperti gen. n., sp. n., and Leptus (Leptus)
   sulawesicus sp. n. all from Indonesia are described. New records for
   Abrolophus aitapensis, Charletonia volzi, C. shiroyama and Leptus
   (Leptus) balicus are given. Grandjeanella multisetosa, G. bella, G.
   haitlingeri, G. kamalii, G. ainae and Hauptmannia ostovani are included
   to the genus Marantelophus gen. n.

DT Article
TI Systematic checklist of the iberocaucasian oribatid mites (Acari:
   Oribatida).
FT Listado sistematico de los acaros oribatidos (Acari: Oribatida)
   iberocaucasicos.
AU Subias, Luis S. (subias@bio.ucm.es) 
   Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 19
PS 55-132
PD 30 Junio 2009(2011)
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A large number of soil samples from the Iberian Peninsula and Caucasus
   are studied. This paper also includes a bibliographical synopsis of all
   the previous records on these rgions, and a systematic checklist with
   1.328 species are given. 869 of them are iberian and 910 are caucasian.
   39 species are new records for the Iberian Peninsula, and 88 are new
   records for the Caucasus; also two new names, three new synonymies and a
   new combination are given: Sellnickochthonius chinonei n. nom.,
   Oribatella (Multoribatella) pseudonigra n. nom., Phthiracarus
   (Archiphthiracarus) stramineus (Koch, 1841) (=Phthiracarus malagensis
   Niedbala, 1986 n. sin.), Hafenferrefia nevesi (Sellnick, 1952)
   (=Hafenrefferiella hyrcanica Krivolutsky, 1967 n. sin.), Anachipteria
   (A.) howardi (Berlese, 1908) (=Oribata perisi Mihelcic, 1956 n. sin.)
   and Macrogena (M.) minor (Subias, Kahwash and Ruiz, 1990) n. comb. The
   genera and subgenera: Neoctenacarus Moritz, 1974, Neobrachychthonius
   Moritz, 1976, Pterochthonius Berlese, 1913, Paratritia Moritz, 1966,
   Nanhermannia (Nippohermannia) P. Balogh, 1985, Parabelbella
   (Tectodamaeus) Aoki, 1984, Subbelba Bulanova-Zachvatkina, 1967,
   Bemdamerus Mahunka, 1977 and Suctobelbila Jacot, 1937, are recorded for
   the first time in Caucasus. The family Parhypochthoniidae Grandjean,
   1932, with its genus Parhypochthonius Berlese, 1984, and the genera
   Reptacarus Perez-Inigo and Pena, 1995, Tectoribates Berlese, 1910 and
   Macrogena Wallwork, 1966, are recorded for the first time in the Iberian
   Peninsula. From the geographical study we concluded that near the half
   of the species, 451, are common to both regions with a high number of
   species of wide distribution, the same that species of endemic and
   Mediterranean distribution.

   Universidad Complutense, Madrid 28040, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI Ground-dwelling spiders (Araneae) in pear orchards in the Oeste region
   of Portugal.
AU Tavares, Catarina A. (ctavares@isa.utl.pl) 
   Gouveia, Filipa
   Oliveira, Nuno G.
   Crespo, Luis Carlos F.
   Mateus, Celia
   Rebelo, M. Teresa
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 19
PS 147-156
PD 30 Junio 2009(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The abundance, species richness, diversity and temporal dynamics of the
   ground dwelling spiders in pear orchards were studied in the Oeste
   region of Portugal. Pitfall traps were used. Six orchards were sampled:
   two of organic agriculture, two under the integrated pest management
   strategy, and two conventional agriculture orchards. In total, 1672
   adult spiders belonging to 73 species and morphospecies and 16 families
   were found. Two species, Zelotes sp.1 and Alopecosa albofasciata (Brune,
   1832), dominate the entire abundance of the community. The diversity of
   spiders is not very high, and is similar in all orchards, except in a
   conventional agriculture one (CA2), which presents the highest abundance
   of both dominant species. A new species to Portugal, Zelotes electus,
   was found.
C1 Tavares, Catarina A.; Biological Resources National Institute (INRB-IP),
   Av. da Republica, Quinta do Marques, 2748-505 Oeiras, Portugal,
   Portugal.
EM ctavares@isa.utl.pl
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1576-9518
BD Ecology; Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Araneae [Community structure /  / ground-dwelling taxa] [Population
   dynamics /  / ] [Cultivated land habitat / Orchard / ] [Portugal / Oeste
   region / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida
OR Araneae (Arachnida).

TI A Revision of Storenosoma Hogg and Description of a New Genus, Oztira
   (Araneae: Amaurobiidae).
AU Milledge, G.A. (graham.milledge@austmus.gov.au) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 63
IS 1
PS 1-32
PD 29 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Storenosoma Hogg, 1900 is revised and now contains thirteen
   species, S. hoggi (Roewer), S. altum Davies, S. supernum Davies, S.
   terraneum Davies, S. bifidum n.sp., S. bondi n.sp., S. forsteri n.sp.,
   S. grayi n.sp., S. grossum n.sp., S. picadilly n.sp., S. smithae n.sp.,
   S. tasmaniensis n.sp., and S. victoria n.sp. A new genus, Oztira, is
   described to contain Australian species previously ascribed to the New
   Zealand genus Otira Forster & Wilton. Oztira contains four species, Oz.
   affinis (Hickman) n.comb., Oz. aquilonaria (Davies) n.comb., Oz. summa
   (Davies) n.comb., and Oz. kroombit n.sp. The relationships between
   Storenosoma, Oztira, Otira and Pakeha are discussed.

DT Article
TI Trapdoor Spiders of the Genus Misgolas (Mygalomorphae: Idiopidae) in the
   Illawarra and South Coast Regions of New South Wales, Australia.
AU Wishart, Graham (gwishart@tpg.com.au) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 63
IS 1
PS 33-51
PD 29 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper reports on species of the idiopid trapdoor spider genus
   Misgolas Karsch, 1878 found in the Illawarra and South Coast Regions of
   New South Wales, Australia. They comprise eight new species: M.
   horsemanae n.sp., M. gwennethae n.sp., M. phippsi n.sp., M. kampenae
   n.sp., M. paulaskewi n.sp., M. rowelli n.sp., M. tannerae n.sp. and M.
   shawi n.sp. Four species dealt with in Wishart (1992) and one in Wishart
   (2006) are also included in the region covered by this work: M. rapax
   (synonymous with M. hubbardi), M. dereki, M. kirstiae, M. robertsi (Main
   & Mascord, 1974) and M. gracilis respectively. M. elegans (Rainbow &
   Pulleine, 1918) is retained here but is regarded as a nomen dubium.
   Evidence is provided supporting the species status of M. montanus
   (Rainbow & Pulleine, 1918). A key for males of the species within the
   region is presented, as well as distribution map and comments on
   taxonomy and natural history.
C1 Wishart, Graham; Australian Museum, 6 Coll St, Sydney, NSW 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM gwishart@tpg.com.au

DT Article
TI New Frogs (Anura: Microhylidae) from the Mountains of Western Papua New
   Guinea.
AU Kraus, Fred (fkraus@hawaii.edu) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 63
IS 1
PS 53-60
PD 29 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB I describe two new species of microhylid frogs from the mountains of the
   central cordillera of western Papua New Guinea. One of these is in the
   arboreal genus Oreophryne; the other is in the fossorial genus
   Xenorhina. The Oreophryne is one of the largest members of the genus and
   is characterized by a ligamentous connection of the procoracoid to the
   scapula, webbing between the toes, fifth toe equal in length to the
   third, and a relatively short leg, wide head, long and narrow snout, and
   small finger discs. The Xenorhina species is among the smallest species
   of the genus and is distinguished by having a single odontoid spike,
   discs with circum-marginal grooves on all toes but the first, inflated
   lores, and a relatively long leg, short and broad head and snout, and
   features of color pattern. The Oreophryne is known from two localities
   approximately 30 km apart, and the Xenorhina is known only from its type
   locality. Both occur in the high mountains of Western Province, Papua
   New Guinea.
C1 Kraus, Fred; Bishop Museum, 1525 Bernice St, Honolulu, HI, USA, USA.
EM fkraus@hawaii.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0067-1975
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia
DE Oreophryne ampelos; Xenorhina brachyrhyncha [Papua New Guinea /  / New
   species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Microhylidae
OR Oreophryne ampelos (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 54]. 
   Xenorhina brachyrhyncha (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P.
   57].

DT Article
TI Australlus, a New Genus for Gallinula disneyi (Aves: Rallidae) and a
   Description of a New Species from Oligo-Miocene Deposits at Riversleigh,
   Northwestern Queensland, Australia.
AU Worthy, Trevor H. (t.worthy@unsw.edu.au) 
   Boles, Walter E.
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 63
IS 1
PS 61-77
PD 29 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Gallinula disneyi Boles, 2005, was based on Late Oligocene-Middle
   Miocene (c. 25-15 Ma) fossils from Riversleigh World Heritage Property
   in Boodjamulla (Lawn Hill) National Park, northwestern Queensland,
   Australia. If the generic assignment is correct, this species would be
   the earliest known crown group representative of Rallidae. We have
   therefore reassessed the phylogenetic relationships of this rail using
   both the original and newly recovered material. It is found to be a
   relatively basal rallid with some affinity to Porphyrio, and the new
   genus Australlus is erected for this taxon. A second species in the
   genus is described from Middle Miocene sites at Riversleigh World
   Heritage Property. A third rallid, smaller than either species of
   Australlus, is indicated by a mandible fragment, also from Riversleigh,
   but is not named. These rails are the only gruiforms known from
   Riversleigh and, with a single species of stork, are the only small
   non-passerine ground-birds known from these faunas.
C1 Worthy, Trevor H.; Univ New S Wales, Sch Biol Earth & Environm Sci,
   Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia, Australia.
EM t.worthy@unsw.edu.au
RI Worthy, Trevor/B-3781-2012
OI Worthy, Trevor/0000-0001-7047-4680
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0067-1975
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Evolution; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia;
   Australia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene;
   Palaeogene
DE Australlus [Miocene /  / New genus] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
   Australlus gagensis [Queensland /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Gallinula disneyi [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic relationships / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Gruiformes, Rallidae

   2005, p. 64, Miocene & Oligocene; Fossil]. 
   Australlus disneyi - (Boles 2005) (Rallidae): [Redescription, P. 64;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Gallinula, p. 64; Fossil]. 
   Australlus gagensis (Rallidae): [Sp nov, Queensland, Miocene, P. 69;
   Fossil]. 
   Gallinula disneyi - Boles 2005 (Rallidae): [Designated type species for
   new genus, Australlus, p. 64].

DT Article
TI Revision of the Tribe Microtrachelizini Zimmerman, 1994, from Australia:
   New Taxa and Records (Insecta: Coleoptera, Brentidae).
AU Mantilleri, Antoine (amantill@mnhn.fr) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 63
IS 1
PS 89-98
PD 29 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Microtrachelizini from Australia are revised. Four species and one
   genus are described as new for science (Araiorrhinus zimmermani n.sp.,
   Howeius micropterus n.gen., n.sp., Microtrachelizus altostriatus n.sp.
   and M. australicus n.sp.). One new synonymy is proposed (M. laevis
   Darnoiseau, 1987 n. syn. of M. montrouzieri Senna, 1903) and two species
   are recorded as new for Australia (M. montrouzieri and M. occultus
   Kleine, 1935, the latter removed from synonymy with M. bhamoensis
   (Senna, 1892)). An identification key and pictures of the habitus are
   given for the nine Microtrachelizini species presently known from
   Australia.

   F-75231, France, France.

TI The Genus Tachydromia Meigen (Diptera: Hybotidae) from Australia.
AU Grootaert, Patrick (Patrick.Grootaert@naturalsciences.be) 
   Shamshev, Igor
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 63
IS 1
PS 103-112
PD 29 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB First data on the genus Tachydromia Meigen from Australia are provided
   including descriptions of five new species: T. australiensis n.sp. (New
   South Wales), T. bickeli n.sp. (New South Wales), T. carnarvonensis
   n.sp. (Queensland), T. corticola n.sp. (New South Wales, Queensland), T.
   nowendociensis n.sp. (New South Wales). Hypothesized phylogenetic
   relationships of the new species (also T. papuana Grootaert known from
   Papua New Guinea) are briefly discussed. A key to Australasian
   Tachydromia is provided.
C1 Grootaert, Patrick; Royal Belgian Inst Nat Sci, Dept Entomol, Rue
   Vautier 29, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM Patrick.Grootaert@naturalsciences.be
RI Shamshev, Igor/A-1697-2014
SC Zoology
SN 0067-1975
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Tachydromia [Australia /  / Key to species]. 
   Tachydromia australiensis; Tachydromia bickeli; Tachydromia
   nowendociensis [New South Wales /  / New species]. 
   Tachydromia carnarvonensis; Tachydromia corticola [Queensland /  / New
   species].

DT Article
TI Three new species of the genus Copaxa Walker, 1855 from Ecuador
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Drei neue Arten der Gattung Copaxa Walker, 1855 aus Ecuador
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Kaech, Horst
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 2
PS 9-15
PD 29 Juni 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 2
AB Three new species of the genus Copaxa WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Ecuador are described and figured: C. winbrechlini n.
   sp. from Esmeraldas and Pichincha provinces, C. carolinae n. sp. from
   Napo and C. simoni n. sp. from Morona Santiago. All holotypes (ex coll.
   Horst KACH, Tumbaco, Ecuador (CHKT)) are deposited in coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) in coil. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which
   later, together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. Two of the species, C.
   carolinae n. sp. and C. simoni n. sp., were reared on Shanchi (Coriaria
   thymifolia (Coriariaceae)) and Avocado (Persea americana (Lauraceae)),
   but unfortunately only as far as the final larval instar (L5). In
   addition, because of multiple original spellings in the descriptions of
   the taxa, Copaxa rufimichoacanensis BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2010 and Copaxa
   rufijaliscensis BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2010, we here act as "First Reviser"
   (Article 19.3 and 24.2 of ICZN 1999) to determine that the correct and
   valid spellings are rufimichoacanensis and n fijaliscensis respectively
   and, following Article 32.4. the incorrect original spellings
   "rufijamichoacanensis" and "rufimijaliscensis" are declared to be
   invalid.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

DT Article
TI Nine new taxa of the genus Automeris Huebner, (1819) (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Neun neue Taxa der Gattung Automeris Huebner, (1819) (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
   van Schayck, Eric
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 2
PS 16-29
PD 29 Juni 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine new taxa of the genus Automeris HUEBNER, (1819) (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured (names are followed by the type
   locality in the format: country (province/department/state)): A. anika
   n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), A. io potosiana n. ssp. (Mexico (San Luis
   Potosi)), A. pueblensis n. sp. (Mexico (Puebla)), A. brenneri n. sp.
   (Mexico (Sonora)), A. siri n. sp. (Mexico (Chiapas)), A. oaxhena n. sp.
   (Mexico (Oaxaca)), A. wenczeli n. sp. (Mexico (SW Oaxaca)), A. mailinae
   n. sp. (Peru (Pasco)) and A. lenarti n. sp. (French Guiana (Cayenne)).
   All holotypes (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), Frank MEISTER,
   Prenzlau (CFMP) or Eric VAN SCHAYCK, Wetter (CEvS)) are deposited in
   CRBP m coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together with
   this collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen
   Muenchen, Munich, Germany. All the new taxa are currently assigned to
   species groups sensu LEMAIRE (2002). A further species group, the
   lauta-species group, is proposed and introduced for the taxa A. lauta
   JOHNSON & MICHENER, 1948, A. anika n. sp. and A. windiana LEMAIRE, 1971.
   In addition, the following three taxa are reinstated from synonymy to
   species status: A. draudtiana LEMAIRE, 1973 stat. nov. (removed from
   synonymy with A. io (FABRICIUS, 1775)), A. angulatus CONTE, 1906 stat.
   rev. (removed from synonymy with A. hamata SCHAUS, 1906) and A. pelaezi
   BEUTELSPACHER-BAIGTS, 1988 stat. rev. (removed from synonymy with A.
   excreta DRAUDT, 1929).
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

TI Ten new species of the genus Janiodes Jordan, 1924 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae, Cercophaninae).
FT Zehn neue Arten der Gattung Janiodes JORDAN, 1924 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae, Cercophaninae, Janiodini).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 2
PS 42-55
PD 29 Juni 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten new species of the genus Janiodes JORDAN, 1924 (Lepidoptera,
   Saturniidae, Cercophaninae, Janiodini) are described and figured (names
   are followed by the type locality in the format: country
   (province/department/state)): J. lucida n. sp. (Peru (Pasco)), J.
   lavernohuanucensis n. sp. (Peru (Huanuco)), J. lavernopascoensis n. sp.
   (Peru (Pasco)), J. lavernodiosianan. sp. (Peru (Madre de Dios)), J.
   lavernocuscoensis n. sp. (Peru (Cusco)), J. lavernoboliviana n. sp.
   (Bolivia (La Paz)), J. peruviana n. sp. (Peru (Pasco)), J. madrediosiana
   n. sp. (Peru (Madre de Dios)), J. piurensis n. sp. (Peru (Piura)) and J.
   meridensis n. sp. (Venezuela (Merida)). All holotype 55 (ex coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) or Frank MEISTER, Prenzlau (CFMP)) are
   deposited in CRBP in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later,
   together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. In addition, to improve the
   clarity of the intrageneric classification, three species groups (not
   valid in sense of the ICZN 1999) are proposed: 1. laverna (DRUCE,
   1890)-group; 2. bethulia (DRUCE, 1904)-group and 3. ecuadorensis
   (DOGNIN, 1890)-group, the latter with two subgroups.
   ecuadorensis-subgroup and russea (DOGNIN, 1911)-subgroup.

AB Fifteen new species of the genus Lonomia WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured: L. paralectra BRECHLIN & MEISTER
   n. sp. from Guatemala (Alta Verapaz), L. mexilectra BRECHLIN & MEISTER
   n. sp. from Mexico (Oaxaca, Chiapas), L. luteomexicana BRECHLIN &
   MEISTER n. sp. from Mexico (Oaxaca, Chiapas), L. yucatensis BRECHLIN &
   MEISTER n. Sp. from Mexico (Campeche, Quintana Roo), L. puntarenasiana
   BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. from Costa Rica (Puntarenas), L.
   orientoandensis BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. from Peru (Amazonas, San
   Martin, Madre de Dios), L. madrediosiana BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. from
   Peru (Madre de Dios), L. maranhensis BRECHLIN, MEISTER & MIELKE n. sp.
   from Brazil (Maranhao), L. sinjaevorum BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. from
   Bolivia (La Paz, Cochabamba), L. viksinyaevi BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   from Bolivia (Santa Cruz), L. canescens BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. from
   Peru (Cusco, Amazonas?), L. rubrescens BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp. from
   Peru (Madre de Dios, Cusco), L. parubrescens BRECHLIN & MEISTER n. sp.
   from Peru (Amazonas, San Martin, Pasco?), L. belizonensis BRECHLIN,
   MEISTER & vary SCHAYCK n. sp. from French Guiana (Cayenne) and L.
   parobliqua BRECHLIN, MEISTER & MIELKE n. Sp. from Paraguay (Alto Parana,
   Caazapa), Argentina (Misiones) and S Brazil (Parana, Santa Catarina, Rio
   Grande do Sul). The holotype of L. maranhensis n. sp. (ex coll. Carlos
   MIELKE, Brazil (CGCM)) will be deposited in the coll. Pe. Jesus S.
   MouRE, Departamento de Zoologia, Universidade Federal do Parana,
   Curitiba, Parana, Brazil; all the other holotypes (ex coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), Frank MEISTER, Prenzlau (CFMP) or Eric VAN
   SCHAYCK, Wetter (CEvS)) are deposited in CRBP in coll. Museum WITT,
   Munich (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will be
   included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. In
   addition, L. concordia DRUCE, 1886 stat. rev. is removed from synonymy
   with L. electra DRUCE, 1886 and reinstated to species rank.

DT Article
TI Five new taxa of the genus Saturnia SCHRANK, 1802 (subgenus Rinaca
   WALKER, 1855) from China (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Fuenf neue Taxa der Gattung Saturnia SCHRANK, 1802 (Subgenus Rinaca
   WALKER, 1855) aus China (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 2
PS 78-85
PD 29 Juni 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new taxa of the genus Saturnia SCHRANK, 1802, subgenus Rinaca
   WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae), from China are described and
   figured: Saturnia (Rinaca) florianii n. sp., S. (R.) saldaitisi n. sp.
   and S. (R.) ruda n. sp. from the province of Sichuan, S. (R.)
   minshanensis n. sp. from Gansu, and S. (R.) chinensis luteoshaanxiana n.
   ssp. from Shaanxi. All holotype as are deposited in coll. Ronald
   BRECHLTN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which
   later, together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. Within this subgenus, S.
   (R.) saldaitisi n. sp., S. (R.) ruda n. sp. and S. (R.) chinensis
   luteoshaanxiana n. ssp. belong to the group of species near S. (R.)
   boisduvalii EVERSMANN, 1846. S. (R.) florianii n. sp. and S. (R.)
   minshanensis n. sp. are close to S. (R.) winbrechlini BRECHLIN, 2000
   from Taibaishan-Mts. (Shaanxi; China). In addition, the female of S.
   (R.) winbrechlini is described and figured for the first time. All the
   new taxa seem to be univoltine with a single flight period in the
   autumn. The females of S. (R) florianii n. sp., S. (R.) minshanensis n.
   sp., S. (R.) saldaitisi n. sp. and S. (R.) chinensis luteoshaanxiana n.
   ssp. and the preimaginal instars of all new taxa remain unknown.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Saturnia (Rinaca) boisduvalii species group; Saturnia (Rinaca)
   winbrechlini species group [Checklists /  / ]. 
   Saturnia (Rinaca) chinensis luteoshaanxiana [Shaanxi /  / New
   subspecies]. 
   Saturnia (Rinaca) florianii; Saturnia (Rinaca) ruda; Saturnia (Rinaca)
   saldaitisi [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
   Saturnia (Rinaca) minshanensis [Gansu /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae

   Saturnia (Rinaca) chinensis luteoshaanxiana (Saturniidae): [Subsp nov,
   Shaanxi, P. 80]. 
   Saturnia (Rinaca) florianii (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P. 78]. 
   Saturnia (Rinaca) minshanensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Gansu, P. 79].

   time described, Female, p. 79; First time figured, Female, p. 84].

AB Six new species of the genus Neodiphthera FLETCHER in FLETCHER & NYE,
   1982 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) from the Indonesian part of the main
   island of New Guinea are described and figured: N. paukstadtorum n. sp.
   (Papua province), N. magodensis n. sp. (Papua province), N. mapiana n.
   sp. (Papua province), N. pelepagana n. sp. (Papua province), N.
   nabiriana n. sp. (Papua province) and N. arfakiana n. sp. (Irian Jaya
   Barat [West Papua province]). All holotypes are deposited in coll.
   Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany),
   which later, together with this collection, will be included in
   Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. N. paukstadtorum
   n. sp. closely resembles N. venusta (ROTHSCHILD & JORDAN, 1907). All the
   other species, N. magodensis n. sp., N. mapiana n. sp., N. pelepaganan.
   sp., N. nabirianan. sp. und N. arfakianan. sp., belong to a species
   complex near N. papuana (ROTHSCHILD, 1904) In addition, N. goodgeri
   (D'ABRERA, 1998) stat. rev. is removed from synonymy with N. papuana and
   reinstated to species rank. The preimaginal instars of all new taxa
   remain
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

AB One new species in the genus Othorene BOISDUVAL, 1872 and one in
   Procitheronia MICHENER, 1949 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae; Ceratocampinae)
   are described and figured: Othorene winbrechlini n. sp., which occurs
   from the Andean area in Bolivia and Peru, eastwards to the Brazilian
   state of Para; and Procitheronia vanschaycki n. sp. from French Guiana.
   Both holotypes are in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll.
   Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this
   collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen,
   Munich, Germany. The preimaginal instars of the new species are unknown.

TI Rhodinia benedeki n. sp., a new saturniid (Lepidoptera) from China.
FT Rhodinia benedeki n. sp., eine neue Saturniide (Lepidoptera) aus China.
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 2
PS 105-107
PD 29 Juni 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Rhodinia STAUDINGER, 1892 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from SW China (Yunnan province), Rhodinia benedeki n. sp.,
   is described and figured. The holotype [male] is deposited in coll.
   Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP)) in coll. Museum WITT, Munich
   (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will be included
   in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. Within the
   genus, R. benedeki n. sp. most closely resembles R. davidi (OBERTHUER,
   1886), but can be distinguished by several external characters. The
   female and the preimaginal instars are unknown.

   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).

PS 5-8
PD 29 Juni 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0

AB Two new species of the genus Automeris HUEBNER, (1819) (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Ecuador are described and both sexes figured: A.
   winbrechlini n. sp. from Loja (type locality (TL)) and Morona Santiago
   provinces and A. doelfi n. sp. from Pichincha (TL) and Imbabura
   provinces. Both holotype 56 are deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN,
   Pasewalk [CRBP], in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later,
   together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. Both new taxa are assigned to
   a new species group (not valid in sense of the ICZN 1999), the
   alticola-species group, which also includes A. alticola LEMAIRE, 1975,
   A. caucensis LEMAIRE, 1976, A. iguaquensis LEMAIRE & AMARILLO, 1992
   andA. napoensis LEMAIRE, 2002. The preimaginal instars of both new taxa
   are unknown.

DT Article
TI Examination of the molecular relationships of sand frogs (Anura:
   Pyxicephalidae: Tomopterna) and resurrection of two species from the
   Horn of Africa.
AU Zimkus, Breda M. (bzimkus@oeb.harvard.edu) 
   Larson, Joanna G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2933
PS 27-45
PD 29 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2933.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02933p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Tomopterna kachowskii and T. elegans from Ethiopia and Somalia, both
   currently synonyms of T. cryptotis, are resurrected based on
   morphological and molecular data. Tomopterna hieroglyphica is determined
   to be conspecific with T. kachowskii, with the latter taking precedence.
   Analysis of mitochondrial 12S rRNA, t-valine, 16S rRNA data reveals that
   these species differ from each other by 7.7%, differ from other
   described species of the genus by at least 3.0% and are only distantly
   related to T. cryptotis. A phylogeny of the genus is constructed, and
   the relationships among species are discussed. Discriminant function
   analysis was completed using 25 morphological measurements to determine
   if the seven clades identified in molecular analyses have concordant
   morphological difference. Translations of the original descriptions are
   provided, and a detailed redescription of T. elegans is included as the
   original description was made with only juvenile specimens. Tomopterna
   kachowskii and T. elegans are distinguished from other species of sand
   frogs by their visible tympana, presence of an outer metatarsal tubercle
   and moderate pedal webbing. Slightly more extensive webbing and variable
   presence of a discontinuous row of small glands beneath the tympanum
   distinguishes T. elegans from T. kachowskii.
C1 Zimkus, Breda M.; Museum of Comparative Zoology and, Department of
   Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University, Cambridge,
   Massachusetts 02138, USA, USA.
EM bzimkus@oeb.harvard.edu
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key;
   Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Afrotropical region
DE Tomopterna [Molecular genetics / mtDNA / taxonomic implications]
   [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ] [Africa /  / ] [ / East Africa /
   Key to species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Tomopterna - Dumeril & Bibron 1841 (Ranidae): [Key to species, Africa,
   East Africa, P. 40]. 
   Tomopterna cryptotis - (Boulenger 1907) (Ranidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Tomopterna elegans (Calabresi 1927), p. 31; Removal from
   synonymy, Tomopterna kachowskii (Nikolskii 1900), p. 31]. 
   Tomopterna elegans - (Calabresi 1927) (Ranidae): [Diagnosis, P. 38;
   Redescription, P. 38; Removal from synonymy, With Tomopterna cryptotis
   (Boulenger 1907), p. 31]. 
   Tomopterna kachowskii - (Nikolskii 1900) (Ranidae): [Diagnosis, P. 38;
   Syn nov, Tomopterna hieroglyphica Ahl 1927, p. 35; Removal from
   synonymy, With Tomopterna cryptotis (Boulenger 1907), p. 31]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.2933.1.2

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069090
DT Article
TI Three New Species of the Genus Photonectes (Teleostei: Stomiiformes:
   Stomiidae: Melanostomiinae) from the Pacific Ocean.
AU Klepadlo, Cynthia (cklepadlo@ucsd.edu) 
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 2
PS 201-210
PD Jun 28 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Three new species of the mesopelagic fish genus Photonectes (Stomiidae,
   Melanostomiinae, subgenus Photonectes) are described from the Pacific
   Ocean with species descriptions augmented by new characters: origin of
   the IP-photophore series, gill-filament length, and jaw-tooth length.
   Photonectes coffer:, new species (central equatorial, north, and western
   Pacific) has an elongate barbel with two bean-shaped light organs; IV
   photophores 37-39; dorsal-fin rays 12-13; no blue luminous tissue; one
   white luminous shoulder spot; all jaw teeth small canines; and gill
   filaments on first arch extending beyond opercular opening. Photonectes
   barnetti, new species (North Pacific Gyre) has an elongate barbel with a
   single ovoid bulb and a white area along the stem; IV photophores 37-39;
   dorsal-fin rays 13-15; no blue luminous tissue; one or two white
   luminous shoulder spots; jaw teeth of variable length; and reduced gill
   filaments on first arch. Photonectes corynodes, new species (central
   equatorial Pacific) is known from a single specimen and has a barbel
   with a single hourglass-shaped bulb and a bifid terminal filament, both
   branches ending in small light organs; IV photophores 34; dorsal-fin
   rays 15; no blue luminous tissue or white luminous shoulder spots; jaw
   teeth of variable length; and gill filaments neither reduced nor
   elongated. A key to the subgenus Photonectes is provided.
C1 Klepadlo, Cynthia; Univ Calif San Diego, Scripps Inst Oceanog, 9500
   Gilman Dr, La Jolla, CA 92093, USA, USA.
EM cklepadlo@ucsd.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Photonectes (Photonectes) barnetti [North Pacific /  / New species]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) coffea; Photonectes (Photonectes) corynodes
   [Pacific Ocean /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Stomiiformes, Melanostomiidae
OR Photonectes (Photonectes) (Melanostomiidae): [Key to species, P. 207]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) barnetti (Melanostomiidae): [Sp nov, North
   Pacific, P. 203]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) coffea (Melanostomiidae): [Sp nov, Pacific
   Ocean, P. 202]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) corynodes (Melanostomiidae): [Sp nov, Pacific
   Ocean, P. 205].

AN ZOOR14709069092
DT Article
TI Two New Genera and Species of Ancistrini (Siluriformes: Loricariidae)
   from the Western Guiana Shield.
AU Lujan, Nathan K. (nklujan@gmail.com) 
   Armbruster, Jonathan W.
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 2
PS 216-225
PD Jun 28 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two new ancistrin genera and species are described from main channels
   and tributaries of the upper Orinoco River in Amazonas, Venezuela.
   Micracanthicus vandragti is black with white spots and distinguished by
   its small body-size, large gas-bladder capsules, and highly protrusible
   mandibles with short tooth cups and five to eight long teeth per tooth
   cup. The known range of Micracanthicus vandragti is restricted to the
   lower Ventuari River and portions of the Orinoco River near its rocky,
   anastomose confluence with the Ventuari River. Soromonichthys stearleyi
   is green with small yellow-gold spots on the head and thin vertical bars
   on the body and has long dentary and premaxillary tooth cups with 39-69
   teeth per tooth cup. It is distinguished by its coloration and by its
   unique pattern of plate loss on the snout: plates absent from mesethmoid
   surface and anteriormost margin of snout. Soromonichthys stearleyi is
   known only from Soromoni Creek, a northern tributary of the upper
   Orinoco draining southern slopes of Mount Duida.
C1 Lujan, Nathan K.; Texas A&M Univ, Dept Wildlife & Fisheries, College
   Stn, TX 77840, USA, USA.
EM nklujan@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Micracanthicus vandragti; Soromonichthys stearleyi [Venezuela /  / New
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Loricariidae
OR Micracanthicus (Loricariidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Ancistrini, Type
   species Micracanthicus vandragti, p. 216]. 
   Micracanthicus vandragti (Loricariidae): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 217]. 
   Soromonichthys (Loricariidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Ancistrini, Type
   species Soromonichthys stearleyi, p. 220]. 
   Soromonichthys stearleyi (Loricariidae): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 222]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709069092
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069093
DT Article
TI A New Genus of Glyptosternine Catfish (Siluriformes: Sisoridae) with
   Descriptions of Two New Species from Yunnan, China.
AU Zhou, Wei (weizhouyn@163.com) 
   Li, Xu
   Thomson, Alfred W.
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 2
PS 226-241
PD Jun 28 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 2
U2 8
AB Creteuchiloglanis, new genus, is established for three species
   previously placed in Pareuchiloglanis (P. gongshanensis, P. kamengensis,
   and P. macropterus) and two new species described herein.
   Creteuchiloglanis is distributed in the upper Mekong River
   (Lancang-Jiang) basin west to the Brahmaputra River basin and is
   distinguished from Pareuchiloglanis by a unique combination of
   characteristics involving the form of the connection of the lower lip to
   the maxillary barbel, premaxillary tooth patches, and the morphology of
   the dilator, operculi, sternohyoideus, and adductor pelvicalis
   superficialis muscles. Creteuchiloglanis brachypterus, new species, from
   the upper Irrawaddy River basin in China, is diagnosed by a unique
   combination of characteristics involving pectoral- and pelvic-fin
   length, caudal-peduncle length and depth, pelvic-fin position,
   caudal-fin length, eye size, body and head depth, and coloration.
   Creteuchiloglanis longipectoralis, new species, from the upper Mekong
   River (Lancang-Jiang) basin, is diagnosed by a unique combination of
   characteristics involving pectoral- and pelvic-fin length,
   caudal-peduncle length and depth, pelvic-fin position, body and head
   depth, post-adipose fin distance, number of dorsal-fin rays, and
   coloration. New diagnoses are provided for previously described
   congeners C. gongshanensis from the upper Salween River (Nu-Jiang)
   basin, C. kamengensis from the Brahmaputra basin, and C. macropterus
   from the upper Irrawaddy River and upper Salween (Nu-Jiang) basins.
C1 Zhou, Wei; SW Forestry Univ, Fac Conservat Biol, Kunming 650224, China,
   China.
EM weizhouyn@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069094
DT Article
TI Osteology Identifies Fundulus capensis Garman, 1895 as a Killifish in
   the Family Fundulidae (Atherinomorpha: Cyprinodontiformes).
AU Parenti, Lynne R. (parentil@si.edu) 
   Hartel, Karsten E.
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 2
PS 242-250
PD Jun 28 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Fundulus capensis Garman, 1895 was described from the unique holotype
   said to be from False Bay, Cape of Good Hope, South Africa. Largely
   ignored by killifish taxonomists, its classification has remained
   ambiguous for over a century. Radiography and computed tomography of the
   holotype reveal skeletal details that have been used in modern
   phylogenetic hypotheses of cyprinodontiform lineages. Osteological
   synapomorphies confirm it is a cyprinodontiform killifish and allow us
   to identify it to species. The first pleural rib on the second vertebra
   and a symmetrical caudal fin with hypural elements fused into a
   fan-shaped hypural plate corroborate its classification in the
   cyprinodontiform suborder Cyprinodontoidel. The twisted maxilla with an
   anterior hook and the premaxilla with an elongate ascending process both
   place it in the family Fundulidae. The pointed neurapophyses of the
   first vertebra that do not meet in the midline and do not form a spine
   exclude it from the family Poeciliidae. Presence of discrete exoccipital
   condyles excludes it from the subfamily Poeciliinae. Overall shape,
   position of fins, and meristic data agree well with those of the
   well-known North American killifish, F. heteroclitus. Fundulus capensis
   Garman, 1895, redescribed herein, is considered a subjective synonym of
   Fundulus heteroclitus (Linnaeus, 1766). Provenance of the specimen
   remains a mystery.
C1 Parenti, Lynne R.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB 37012,NHB
   MRC 159, Washington, DC 20013, USA, USA.
EM parentil@si.edu
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0045-8511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Fundulus capensis [Skeleton / Osteology / Systematics] [South Atlantic /
   South Africa, False Bay / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontiformes, Cyprinodontidae
OR Fundulus capensis - Garman 1895 (Cyprinodontidae): [Redescription, P.
   243]. 
   Fundulus heteroclitus - (Linnaeus 1766) (Cyprinodontidae): [Syn nov,
   Fundulus capensis Garman 1895, p. 247]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709069094
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A New Species of Hemigrammus from the Lower Amazon Floodplain
   (Characiformes: Characidae).
AU Mendonca, Marina B. (marinab_m@yahoo.com.br) 
   Wosiacki, Wolmar B.
SO Copeia
VL 2011
IS 2
PS 211-215
PD Jun 28 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Hemigrammus diagonicus, new species, is described from the lower Amazon
   River floodplain, near Juruti, State of Para, Brazil. The new species
   shares with H. silimoni the presence of a dark blotch on the dorsal lobe
   of the caudal fin, absent in all other species of the genus. It is
   distinguished from H. silimoni by the autapomorphic presence of the
   caudal-fin blotch shaped like a bar that extends diagonally from the
   base of the median rays to the end of the upper lobe rays. Hemigrammus
   diagonicus, new species, is further distinguished from H. silimoni by a
   combination of meristic and morphometric characters, such as length of
   anal-fin base and horizontal eye diameter. Comments on the color
   patterns displayed by the species of Hemigrammus are presented.
C1 Mendonca, Marina B.; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, Caixa Postal 399,
   Belem, Para, BR-66040-170, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI Kiwigaster gen. nov. (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) from New Zealand: the
   first Microgastrinae with sexual dimorphism in number of antennal
   segments.
AU Fernandez-Triana, J.L. (jftriana@uoguelph.ca) 
   Ward, D.F.
   Whitfield, J.B.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2932
PS 24-32
PD 28 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2932.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02932p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new and morphologically unusual genus of microgastrine Braconidae,
   Kiwigaster Fernandez-Triana, Whitfield and Ward, with one new species,
   K. variabilis Fernandez-Triana and Ward, is described from New Zealand,
   where it is widespread. A number of morphological features mark it as
   unique among Microgastrinae, the most striking being the males and
   females having different numbers of antennal flagellomeres (females 17,
   males 18). Other unusual characters suggest this may be the most
   early-diverging extant species of the subfamily, although comprehensive
   phylogenetic analyses have yet to be conducted. Nothing is yet known
   about its host(s) or other aspects of its biology.
C1 Fernandez-Triana, J.L.; Biodiversity Institute of Ontario, University of
   Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, N1G 2W1, Canada, Canada.

TI Description and phylogenetic position of a new Willemia species
   (Collembola: Hypogastruridae) from the littoral coast of Brazil.
AU D'Haese, Cyrille A. (dhaese@mnhn.fr) 
   Thibaud, Jean-Marc
SO Zootaxa
VL 2932
PS 33-40
PD 28 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2932.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02932p040.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new psammobiontic Willemia species from Brazil is described and
   illustrated: W. zeppelini sp. nov. The phylogeny for all the 43 species
   of the genus Willemia is proposed comprising the new species and 8
   species not included in D'Haese (2000) work. The new species is well
   defined with a unique Ant. III organ and one hr chaeta per anal valve
   among other characters. W. zeppelini is sister group to the
   buddenbrocki-group. An identification key for all known species of the
   genus is provided.

DT Article
TI Contribution to the taxonomy of the Hylaeus gibbus species group in
   Europe (Hymenoptera, Apoidea and Colletidae).
AU Straka, Jakub (straka.jakub.1@gmail.com) 
   Bogusch, Petr
SO Zootaxa
VL 2932
PS 51-67
PD 28 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2932.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02932p067.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB We redescribe and present new diagnoses of the Hylaeus gibbus group in
   Europe. Species of this group were often confused with each other. Our
   method of distinguishing between the species is based on dividing three
   commonly recognised species into four. We present diagnoses and list the
   characteristics of Hylaeus confusus Nylander, 1852; Hylaeus gibbus
   Saunders, 1850; and Hylaeus pictus (Smith, 1853). For the newly
   characterised form, one of Foerster's available names has been
   resurrected[long dash]Hylaeus incongruus Foerster, 1871. Hylaeus gibbus
   occurs only in southern Europe and northern to southern parts of central
   Europe, while H. incongruus reaches more northern latitudes. Types of
   the most problematic and poorly described forms were examined. Some
   names of clearly lost types were fixed by designating neotypes.
C1 Straka, Jakub; Department of Zoology, Charles University in Prague,
   Vinicna 7, CZ[long dash]12844 Praha 2, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

   P. 61].

TI A remarkable new genus of Dikraneurini (Hemiptera: Cicadomorpha:
   Cicadellidae: Typhlocybinae) from Southeast Asia.
AU Viraktamath, C.A.
   Dietrich, C.H. (dietrich@inhs.uiuc.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2931
PS 1-7
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2931.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02931p007.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Sweta gen. n. is described and illustrated based on type species S.
   hallucinata sp. n. from northeast India and Thailand and placed in the
   typhlocybine tribe Dikraneurini. The new genus is unique among known
   Typhlocybinae in having the pronotum enlarged and extended to the
   scutellar suture. This feature is characteristic of the related
   subfamily Signoretiinae, but among other subfamilies is restricted to a
   few brachypterous forms.

DT Article
TI Pteroptyx maipo Ballantyne, a new species of bent-winged firefly
   (Coleoptera: Lampyridae) from Hong Kong, and its relevance to firefly
   biology and conservation.
AU Ballantyne, Lesley (lballantyne@csu.edu.au) 
   Fu, Xin Hua
   Shih, Chun-Hat
   Cheng, Chui-Yu
   Yiu, Vor
SO Zootaxa
VL 2931
PS 8-34
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2931.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02931p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Pteroptyx maipo sp. nov. is the first record of the genus Pteroptyx
   Olivier from mainland China and Hong Kong and represents the most
   northerly record for this genus. The description includes all life
   stages: egg, larva, pupa and adult, and covers special structures such
   as the female bursa plates and male copulatory clamp. Details of
   habitat, male courtship flash patterns and male-female courtship
   behaviour are described. This species is the second in the genus
   Pteroptyx found to use a copulatory clamp, which functions to wedge the
   mating pair together. A complete clamp however does not appear necessary
   for successful insemination. Bursa plates hold the spermatophore
   partially projecting into a spermatophore-digesting gland. Other
   functions for the plates are investigated and discussed. The deflexed
   elytral apex appears after eclosion in the adult male. Mechanisms for
   the loss of ventrite 8 in the male abdomen are explored. A list of the
   30 Pteroptyx species recognised here, with habitats, some morphological
   characteristics and a key to species of the Oriental Pteroptyx are
   provided.
C1 Ballantyne, Lesley; School of Agricultural and Wine Sciences, Charles
   Sturt University, PO Box 588, Wagga Wagga 2678, Australia, Australia.
EM lballantyne@csu.edu.au
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Pteroptyx [Checklists / Annotated taxonomic checklist / ] [Asia / South
   east / Key to species] [China /  / New record] [Hong Kong /  / ]. 
   Pteroptyx maipo [Hong Kong /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cantharoidea,
   Lampyridae
OR Pteroptyx - Olivier (Lampyridae): [Key to species, Asia, South east,
   Males, p. 11; New record]. 
   Pteroptyx maipo (Lampyridae): [Sp nov, Hong Kong, P. 13]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14708061572
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14708061573
DT Article
TI Brief Summary of Holochlorini (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae:
   Phaneropterinae), with Description of Seven New Species from China.
AU Liu, Chun-Xiang (liucx@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2931
PS 35-52
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2931.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02931p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Inclusion of the tribe Holochlorini has been questionable, for its
   complicated history and its controversial important diagnostic character
   about structure of tibial tympana. Here we briefly introduce its history
   and summarize its inclusion in the world and in China. We also introduce
   a newly recorded genus from China, Arnobia, and other two genera in the
   tribe, Psyrana and Phaulula, provide a list of Chinese species for the
   three genera, separately, together with the key to species of the three
   genera. At the same time, we describe seven new species to science in
   the Holochlorini, i.e., Arnobia hainanensis sp. nov., Arnobia
   guangxiensis sp. nov., Phaulula apicalis sp. nov., Psyrana magna sp.
   nov., Psyrana heptagona sp. nov., Parapsyra brevicauda sp. nov., and
   Sinochlora semicircula sp. nov. Diagnostic illustrations are presented.
C1 Liu, Chun-Xiang; Key Laboratory of Zoological Systematics and Evolution,
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080,
   China, China.
EM liucx@ioz.ac.cn

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Arnobia guangxiensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Guangxi Zhuang, P. 39].

AN ZOOR14708061574
DT Article
TI Triskelionia, a new African genus of the Celaenorrhinini (Lepidoptera:
   Hesperiidae) and the promotion of T. compacta to species-status.
AU Larsen, Torben B. (torbenlarsen@btinternet.com) 
   Congdon, T. Colin E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2931
PS 53-58
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2931.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02931p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Triskelionia is defined and described as a new genus for the
   Afrotropical skipper known as Sarangesa tricerata (Mabille, 1891)
   (Hesperiidae, Pyrginae, Celaenorrhinini). Its subspecies S. tricerata
   compacta Evans, 1937 is raised to species rank. The host plant is
   Dalbergia armata (Fabaceae) and it is the only known member of the
   African Celaenorrhinini that does not have Acanthaceae as host-plant and
   the pupa is the only one known without a free proboscis sheath.
C1 Larsen, Torben B.; Jacobys alle 2, Frederiksberg, DK 1806, Denmark,
   Denmark.
EM torbenlarsen@btinternet.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Ctenuchidae, Papilionoidea, Hesperiidae
OR Hyda tricerata - Mabille 1891 (Ctenuchidae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Triskelionia, p. 54]. 
   Sarangesa tricerata - (Mabille 1891) (Hesperiidae): [Referred to, New
   genus Triskelionia, p. 54]. 
   Sarangesa tricerata compacta - Evans 1951 (Hesperiidae): [Referred with
   status upgrading to, New genus Triskelionia, p. 55]. 
   Triskelionia (Hesperiidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Celaenorrhinini, Type
   species Hyda tricerata Mabille 1891, p. 54]. 
   Triskelionia compacta - (Evans 1951) (Hesperiidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred with status upgrading from Sarangesa tricerata, p. 55]. 
   Triskelionia tricerata - (Mabille 1891) (Hesperiidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Sarangesa, p. 54].

AN ZOOR14708061565
DT Article
TI A new species of karst dwelling Cyrtodactylus (Squamata: Gekkonidae)
   from northwestern Laos.
AU Schneider, Nicole
   Nguyen, Truong Quang
   Schmitz, Andreas
   Kingsada, Phouthone
   Auer, Markus
   Ziegler, Thomas (ziegler@koelnerzoo.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2930
PS 1-21
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2930.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02930p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of the gekkonid genus Cyrtodactylus from
   northwestern Laos, based on a recent collection from Vientiane Province.
   Cyrtodactylus pageli sp. n. is distinguished from the remaining
   bent-toed-geckos by the combination of the following characters:
   snout-vent length up to 81.8 mm; 9[long dash]12 supralabials; 9
   infralabials; 9[long dash]14 rows of dorsal tubercles; no distinct
   lateral body fold; 41[long dash]46 midbody ventrals; precloacal pores
   present in both sexes (males 4, females 5 or 6); no precloacal groove;
   femoral scales not distinctly enlarged; no femoral pores; subdigital
   lamellae under the fourth toe 19[long dash]26; subcaudals transversally
   enlarged; dark nuchal band, followed by a transversal row of dark neck
   blotches (rarely forming an additional transversal neck band) in-between
   nuchal band and first body band; 5 in part irregular dark dorsal bands
   between limb insertions plus transversal band between hind limbs; tail
   with banded pattern.
C1 Ziegler, Thomas; Zoologischer Garten Koeln, Riehler Strasse 173, D-50735
   Koeln, Germany, Germany.
EM ziegler@koelnerzoo.de
RI Nguyen, Truong/F-3730-2012
OI Nguyen, Truong/0000-0002-6601-0880
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cyrtodactylus pageli [Laos /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus pageli (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 6].
