AN ZOOR14708061566
DT Article
TI A new species of bent-toed gecko (Cyrtodactylus, Gekkonidae) from the
   North Papuan Mountains.
AU Oliver, Paul (paul.oliver@adelaide.edu.au) 
   Krey, Keliopas
   Mumpuni
   Richards, Stephen
SO Zootaxa
VL 2930
PS 22-27
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2930.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02930p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of Cyrtodactylus from lower montane forests on
   the Torricelli and Foja Mountain ranges of northern New Guinea.
   Cyrtodactylus boreoclivus sp. nov. can be distinguished from all other
   described Cyrtodactylus by the combination of moderately large size (SVL
   104[long dash]109 mm), males with pores extending to the knee and
   arranged in independent precloacal and femoral series, transversely
   enlarged subcaudal scales, and dorsal pattern consisting of five to
   seven indistinct transverse dark bands. The known distribution of this
   species is similar to many other vertebrate taxa apparently restricted
   to isolated ranges within the North Papuan Mountains, and supports the
   biogeographic association of these poorly known upland areas.
C1 Oliver, Paul; Terrestrial Vertebrates, South Australian Museum, North
   Terrace, Adelaide, S.A, 5000, Australia, Australia.
EM paul.oliver@adelaide.edu.au
OI Oliver, Paul/0000-0003-4291-257X
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia
DE Cyrtodactylus boreoclivus [Indonesia /  / New species] [Papua New Guinea
   /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus boreoclivus (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P.
   23].

DT Article
TI Two new species of cirolanid isopods (Crustacea: Isopoda: Cirolanidae)
   from Qeshm and Kish Islands in the Persian Gulf.
AU Khalaji-Pirbalouty, Valiallah (vkhalaji@uni-bonn.de) 
   Waegele, Johann-Wolfgang
SO Zootaxa
VL 2930
PS 33-46
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2930.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02930p046.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of cirolanid isopods, Baharilana kiabii sp. nov. from
   the western coasts of Qeshm Island and Cirolana tarahomii sp. nov. from
   the northern cost of Kish Island and the western coasts of Qeshm Island
   in the Persian Gulf are described. Baharilana kiabii sp. nov. is
   characterized by pleonite 5 with a median projection and a pleotelson
   with two longitudinal, parallel ridges and small tubercles on the dorsal
   surface. Cirolana tarahomii sp. nov. is distinguished by a lateral
   margins of the frontal lamina converging slightly towards the base, the
   distal margin is extended with a narrowly rounded apex; appendix
   masculina distally acute with bifid apex, pleotelson with a broadly
   rounded apex and 8 marginal robust setae, uropodal rami not deeply
   bifid.
C1 Khalaji-Pirbalouty, Valiallah; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum, Alexander
   Koenig, Rheinische Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universitaet Bonn, Adenauerallee
   160, 53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM vkhalaji@uni-bonn.de
OI Khalaji-Pirbalouty, Valiallah/0000-0002-0892-7463

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Indian Ocean
DE Baharilana kiabii; Cirolana tarahomii [Persian Gulf / Iran / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

AN ZOOR14708061570
DT Article
TI A new species of Tropidurus (Squamata, Tropiduridae) of the
   semitaeniatus group from a semiarid area in Northeastern Brazil.
AU Passos, Daniel Cunha (biologodanielpassos@gmail.com) 
   Lima, Daniel Cassiano
   Borges-Nojosa, Diva Maria
SO Zootaxa
VL 2930
PS 60-68
PD 27 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2930.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02930p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Tropidurus of the semitaeniatus group is described from
   northeastern Brazil. Tropidurus sp. nov. is morphologically similar to
   other species of the group in the marked dorsoventral flattening of the
   body, and the presence of a series of sublabial shields that are larger
   than the adjacent scales. It is distinguished by a single middorsal
   longitudinal light stripe that extends from the snout to the scapular
   region. The new species appears to have the largest body size of the
   group. The new species inhabits the Vale do Jaguaribe, in the eastern
   part of the state of Ceara, where there are many fissured rocky outcrops
   surrounded by hypoxerophytic caatinga vegetation.
C1 Passos, Daniel Cunha; Nucleo Regional de Ofiologia da Universidade
   Federal do Ceara [long dash] NUROF-UFC, Campus do Pici, Centro de
   Ciencias, Bloco 905, 60.455-760, Fortaleza, Ceara, Brazil, Brazil.
EM biologodanielpassos@gmail.com
OI Passos, Daniel/0000-0002-4378-4496
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Tropidurus jaguaribanus [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Tropidurus semitaeniatus group [Brazil / North east / Key to species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Tropidurus jaguaribanus (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 61]. 
   Tropidurus semitaeniatus group (Iguanidae): [Key to species, Brazil,
   North east, P. 67].

AN ZOOR14712083897
DT Article
TI Two New Species of Tetrigoidea (Orthoptera) from Guangdong Province.
AU Cao, Cheng-quan
   Zheng, Zhe-min
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 33
IS 2
PS 97-100
PD Jun 25 2011
PY 2011
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Tetrigoidea are described. Type specimens are
   deposited in the Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University. 1.
   Mazarredia serrifenzura Zheng et Cao, sp. nov. (Figs. 1, 2) This new
   species is allied to Mazarredia guangxiensis Zheng et Jiang, 1998 and
   Mazarredia jiangxiensis Zheng et Shi, 2009. It differs from both in: 1)
   width of vertex 1.25 times the width of an eye; 2) hind process of
   pronotum nearly reaching top of hind tibia; 3) width of midfemur equal
   to the width of tegmina; 4) lower outer side of hind femur black; 5)
   hind tibia black. It differs from M. guangxiensis in: 1) humeral angle
   obtuse angular; 2) with a pair short longitudinal keels between
   shoulders. It differs from M. guangxiensis in: 1) antennae inserted
   under the lower margin of eyes; 2) lateral keels of prozona contract
   backward. Length of body: [male]10.00 mm; length of pronotuom:
   ([male]14.00 mm; length of hind femur: [male]7.00 mm. Holotype: [male],
   Ruyuan County, Guangdong Province, 800 m, 24[degree]53[minute]N,
   113[degree]01[minute]E; 24-VIII-2010; collected by HUANG Cheng-jun.
   Etymology: The specific epithet is derived from the Latin "serri" and
   "femur". 2. Fornzosatettix nanlingensis Zheng et Cao, sp. nov. (Figs.
   3-5) This new species is allied to Formosatettix formosanus (Shiraki,
   1906), but differs in: 1) width of vertex 2 times the width of an eye;
   2) hind process reaching knee of hind femur; 3) lower margins of fore
   and middle femur straight; 4) hind tibia black, basal part light color;
   5) size larger, length of body 14.00 mm. Length of body: [male]11.00 mm,
   [female]14.00 mm; length of pronotum: [male]9.00 mm, [female]10.00 mm;
   length of hind femur: [male]6.00 mm; [female]7.50 mm. Holotype: Ruyuan
   County, Guangdong Province, 800 m, 24[degree]53[minute]N,
   113[degree]01[minute]E; 24-VIII-2010; collected by HUANG Cheng-jun;
   Paratpype: 1[female], same data as holotype. Etymology: The specific
   epithet is derived from the type locality "Nanling" and the suffix
   "-ensis" indicating "residing in".
C1 Cao, Cheng-quan; Leshan Normal Univ, Coll Chem & Life Sci, Leshan,
   Sichuan, 614004, China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Formosatettix nanlingensis; Mazarredia serrifemura [Guangdong /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Formosatettix nanlingensis - Zheng & Cao 2011 (Saltatoria): [Sp nov,
   Guangdong, P. 100]. 
   Mazarredia serrifemura - Zheng & Cao 2011 (Saltatoria): [Sp nov,
   Guangdong, P. 100].

DT Article
TI A New Cave-dwelling Species of the Genus Itamus Schmidt-Gobel (Insecta:
   Coleoptera: Carabidae: Paussinae) from Southern Vietnam.
AU Tian, Ming-yi (mytian@scau.edu.cn) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 33
IS 2
PS 112-117
PD Jun 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Itamus deuvei, sp. nov. is described from Tan Phu, near Ho Chi Minh
   City, southern Vietnam, based on seven specimens collected in a lava
   tube system. It is the second troglophile species of the genus Itamus
   Schmidt-Gobel and is easily distinguished from I. cavicola (Moore), the
   other troglophile from Papua New Guinea, by its more elongate body,
   longer antennae, head without a supraorbital setiferous pore, and very
   shallow and impunctate elytral striae.
C1 Tian, Ming-yi; S China Agr Univ, Coll Nat Resources & Environm,
   Guangzhou, Guangdong, 510640, China, China.
EM mytian@scau.edu.cn

DT Article
TI Matrilineal History of the Rana longicrus Species Group (Rana, Ranidae,
   Anura) and the Description of a New Species from Hunan, Southern China.
AU Yan, Fang
   Jiang, Ke
   Chen, Hongman
   Fang, Ping
   Jin, Jieqiong
   Li, Yi
   Wang, Shaoneng
   Murphy, Robert W.
   Che, Jing (chej@mail.kiz.ac.cn) 
   Zhang, Yaping
SO Asian Herpetological Research
VL 2
IS 2
PS 61-71
PD Jun 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Fieldwork in Jiemuxi National Nature Reserve, Hunan, China, discovered
   morphologically indistinguishable groups of brown frogs that bred at
   different, exclusive times of the year. A principal components analysis
   of morphometric data, molecular analyses, and the exclusive breeding
   season suggested the occurrence of two species. The population that
   breeds during the winter was found to be an undescribed species and was
   subsequently described as Rana jiemuxiensis sp. nov. The new cryptic
   species can be identified from its congeners at the same locality by
   having a different breeding season and a divergent DNA barcode. Six
   major lineages of brown frogs were resolved with high nodal support.
   Rana japonica, R. chaochiaoensis, R. omeimontis, and R. jiemuxiensis
   have independent maternal lineages. Rana hanlunica and R. maoershanensis
   have essentially identical maternal lineages and they appear to
   represent the same species. The validity of the species R. longicrus, R.
   zhenhaiensis, and R. culaiensis and their genealogical relationships are
   not resolved and deserve further study. The genealogy indicates that
   sympatric cryptic lineages probably widely exist in the R. longierus
   group. This highlights the importance of future more fine-scaled
   samplings and the inclusion of nuclear genes.
C1 Che, Jing; Chinese Acad Sci, Kunming Inst Zool, Kunming, Yunnan 650223,
   China, China.
EM chej@mail.kiz.ac.cn
OI Murphy, Robert/0000-0001-8555-2338
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Rana chaochiaoensis; Rana hanluica; Rana zhenhaiensis [Biometrics /
   Morphometrics / Taxonomic implications] [Molecular genetics / DNA
   barcode / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [China /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Rana culaiensis; Rana japonica; Rana longicrus; Rana omeimontis
   [Molecular genetics / DNA barcode / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [China /  / ]. 
   Rana jiemuxiensis [Biometrics / Morphometrics / Taxonomic implications]
   [Molecular genetics / DNA barcode / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [China /  / ] [
   /  / ] [Hunan /  / New species]. 
   Rana omeinontis [Biometrics / Morphometrics / Taxonomic implications]
   [China /  / ].

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Feirana (Amphibia: Anura: Dicroglossidae)
   from the Western Qinling Mountains of China.
AU Yang, Xin
   Wang, Bin
   Hu, Junhua
   Jiang, Jianping (jiangjp@cib.ac.cn) 
SO Asian Herpetological Research
VL 2
IS 2
PS 72-86
PD Jun 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 2
U2 14
AB A new species, Feirana kangxianensis sp. nov., is described from the
   western Qinling Mountains in Gansu, China. Both morphological and
   molecular data support its validity. The new species is characterized
   by: (1) presence of keratinized nuptial spines on the thenar region of
   the hands in males of the new species, in contrast to F. taihangnica and
   E quadranus; (2) of females, the ratios of UEW, INS, NSD and IPTL to SVL
   of F. kangxianensis were significantly less than those of F. taihangnica
   and F quadranus (P < 0.05), while the ratio of IOS to SVL of the new
   species was significantly larger than that of the latter two species (P
   < 0.05); and (3) of males, the ratios of INS, NSD, IPTW to SVL of the
   new species were significantly less than those of F. taihangnica and E
   quadranus (P < 0.05), while the ratio of HL to SVL of the former was
   significantly larger than that of the latter, and the ratio of HW to SVL
   of F kangxianensis was significantly larger than that of E taihangnica
   but less than that of F. quadranus, the ratio of OPTL to SVL of E
   kangxianensis was significantly less than that of F taihangnica but
   larger than that of E quadranus (P < 0.05). The three species of Feirana
   can be easily identified and significantly differ from each other by the
   canonical discriminant analyses with high correct classification (>92%).
   Concurrently, based on partial mitochondrial ND2 gene sequences, the
   result of the molecular phylogenetic analyses of the Feirana indicates
   that the E kangxianensis is sister to E taihangnica.
C1 Jiang, Jianping; Chinese Acad Sci, Chengdu Inst Biol, Chengdu, Sichuan
   610041, China, China.
EM jiangjp@cib.ac.cn
RI hu, jh/B-4853-2010
OI hu, jh/0000-0002-6669-8443
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Feirana kangxianensis [Gansu /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Feirana kangxianensis (Ranidae): [Sp nov, Gansu, P. 80].

DT Article
TI The genus Mallacoota (Crustacea, Amphipoda, Maeridae) in New Zealand.
AU Kilgallen, Niamh M.
   Ahyong, Shane T. (shane.ahyong@austmus.gov.au) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2929
PS 22-36
PD 24 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2929.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02929p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The New Zealand species of the amphipod crustacean genus Mallacoota are
   revised. Previous records of Mallacoota subcarinata (Haswell, 1879) from
   New Zealand are based on a new species, Mallacoota chiltoni sp. nov. and
   M. petriei (Thomson, 1882), which is re-established as valid based on a
   neotype. Mallocoota chiltoni apparently has a southern distribution in
   New Zealand, occurring only south of the Subtropical Convergence,
   whereas M. petriei ranges widely in both the north and south islands. A
   history of the genus Mallacoota in New Zealand is given.
C1 Ahyong, Shane T.; Australian Museum, 6 College St, Sydney, NSW 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM shane.ahyong@austmus.gov.au

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   Mallacoota chiltoni [South Pacific / New Zealand / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Amphipoda
OR Mallacoota - Barnard 1972 (Amphipoda). 
   Mallacoota chiltoni (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, New Zealand (marine), P. 23]. 
   Mallacoota petriei - (Thomson 1882) (Amphipoda): [Description, P. 29;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Moera, p. 29; Stat nov, P. 29]. 
   Moera petriei - Thomson 1882 (Amphipoda): [Neotype designated, P. 34;
   Referred to, Mallacoota, p. 29].

DT Article
TI A new species of Sandro Karaman & Barnard (Crustacea: Amphipoda:
   Austroniphargus family group) from South-East Madagascar.
AU Daneliya, Mikhail E. (mikhail.daneliya@helsinki.fi) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2929
PS 37-50
PD 24 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2929.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02929p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new austroniphargid amphipod Sandro straussi sp. n. (Crustacea,
   Amphipoda, Austroniphargus family group) is described on a large
   collection from forest streams of the Ranomafana National Park,
   South-East Madagascar. The new species differs from the only known
   congener, S. starmuehlneri (Ruffo, 1960), by the absence of dorsal
   spine-setae on telson, unlobed propodus of gnathopods, presence of
   distal bifurcation on posterior lobe of male uropod 3 peduncle and other
   characters. The unique feature of S. straussi sp. n. is the sexual
   dimorphism of uropods 1 and 3: males of the species possess a
   distolateral lobe on the uropod 1 peduncle and mentioned bifurcated lobe
   on uropod 3. Despite the absence of eyes, S. straussi sp. n. is widely
   distributed in epigean stream of the Ranomafana National Park. The
   diagnosis of the genus Sandro Karaman & Barnard, 1979 is revised and a
   key to austroniphargid species is composed.
C1 Daneliya, Mikhail E.; Finnish Museum of Natural History, POB 17,
   FI-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland, Finland.
EM mikhail.daneliya@helsinki.fi
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Sandro straussi [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Amphipoda
OR Austroniphargus group (Amphipoda): [Key to species, P. 50]. 
   Sandro - Karaman & Barnard 1979 (Amphipoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 39].
   
   Sandro straussi (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 40].

TI NEMOURA JEJUDOENSIS A NEW SPECIES OF STONEFLY AND THE REDESCRIPTION OF
   AMPHINEMURA BAEI HAM AND LEE (PLECOPTERA, NEMOURIDAE) FROM JEJU ISLAND,
   KOREA.

   Baumann, Richard W.

PD 23 June 2011

U1 0

AB Nemoura jejudoensis sp. n. is described from specimens collected on Jeju
   Island, Korea. A detailed redescription is given of Amphinemura baei Ham
   and Lee 1999, including new illustrations and scanning electron
   micrographs of adult genitalia based on numerous specimens collected
   from Jeju Island. In addition, a list of miscellaneous stonefly species
   from Korea is included based on specimens housed in the Monte L. Bean
   Life Science Museum, Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah USA.

DT Article
TI The remarkable squidworm is an example of discoveries that await in
   deep-pelagic habitats.
AU Osborn, Karen J. (kosborn@ucsc.edu) 
   Madin, Laurence P.
   Rouse, Greg W.
SO Biology Letters
VL 7
IS 3
PS 449-453
PD Jun 23 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB An intriguing new annelid, Teuthidodrilus samae (Annelida,
   Cirratuliformia) gen. and sp. nov., was observed and collected during
   deep-water column exploration of the western Celebes Sea. The Celebes
   Sea is a deep pocket basin, effectively isolated from surrounding deep
   water, and is part of the Coral Triangle, a focal area for conservation
   because of its high diversity and unique geological history. Collected
   specimens reached 94 mm in length and possessed 10 anterior appendages
   that were as long or longer than the body. Two characters distinguish T.
   samae from other polychaetes: notochaetae forming broad, concavo-convex
   paddles and six pairs of free-standing, oppositely branched nuchal
   organs. Phylogenetic analysis of five genes and a 29-character
   morphological matrix showed that T. samae is an acrocirrid (primarily
   benthic polychaetes) belonging to the morphologically diverse swimming
   clade. Pelagic animals within primarily benthic clades are of particular
   interest in evolutionary biology, because their adaptations to life in
   the water column inform us of the evolutionary possibilities and
   constraints within the clade and indirectly of the selective pressures
   at work in this unfamiliar habitat. This new genus illustrates how much
   we have to learn about even the large, abundant inhabitants of
   deep-pelagic communities.
C1 Osborn, Karen J.; Univ Calif Santa Cruz, Inst Marine Sci, 1156 High St,
   Santa Cruz, CA, USA, USA.
EM kosborn@ucsc.edu
RI Osborn, Karen/E-9222-2011; Rouse, Greg W/F-2611-2010
OI Rouse, Greg W/0000-0001-9036-9263; Osborn, Karen/0000-0002-4226-9257
SC Zoology
SN 1744-9561
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Teuthidodrilus samae [North Pacific / Philippines / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Teuthidodrilus (Polychaeta): [Gen nov, Of family Acrocirridae, Type
   species Teuthidodrilus samae, p. 450]. 
   Teuthidodrilus samae (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Philippines (marine), P.
   450]. 
DI 10.1098/rsbl.2010.0923
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14708055800
OA Green Published, Bronze

AB A synopsis of the genus Oxathres Bates, 1864 is presented. Three new
   species are described: Oxathres guyanensis sp. nov. from French Guiana
   and Brazil (Rondonia), O. boliviana sp. nov. and O. maculosa sp. nov.
   from Bolivia (Santa Cruz, La Paz). A key for the species is provided.
   All the species are illustrated.

TI A Taxonomic Study of the Scaly Cricket Family Mogoplistidae (Orthoptera:
   Ensifera: Grylloidea) in Korea.
AU Kim, Taewoo (pulmuchi@korea.kr) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2928
PS 41-48
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2928.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02928p048.pdf
LA English
U1 2
U2 4
AB The little-known scaly cricket family Mogoplistidae is reviewed for
   Korea for the first time. Three members are confirmed: Ectatoderus tamna
   sp. nov. is newly described from Jejudo Island; Ornebius bimaculatus
   (Shiraki, 1930) is newly recognized from Marado Island, a small island
   near Jejudo Island; and Ornebius kanetataki (Matsumura, 1904) is
   reconfirmed. A key to the species, descriptions, photographs, and
   figures are provided for their identification. All type and voucher
   specimens are deposited in the Entomological Collection of the National
   Institute of Biological Resources.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Hilara (Diptera, Empididae) from northwestern Turkey.
AU Ciftci, Mustafa Cemal (empididae@gmail.com) 
   Hasbenli, Abdullah
SO Zootaxa
VL 2928
PS 49-56
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2928.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02928p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species, Hilara deryae sp. nov. (Hilara clavipes-group) and
   Hilara hasankoci sp. nov. (Hilara interstinctagroup) are described from
   northwestern Turkey. The male and female stages are described, compared
   with related species and male genitalia and forelegs illustrated. Keys
   to the western Palaearctic species of Hilara clavipes-group and the
   Mediterranean species of Hilara interstincta-group are updated. Also the
   systematic position of the new species within the species groups is
   discussed.

AN ZOOR14708061261
DT Article
TI Promanodes alleni sp. nov., the second species of the Tertiary genus
   Promanodes Kolibae, Schmied, Wappler et Kubisz, 2010, with improved
   diagnosis of the genus and remarks on its phylogeny (Coleoptera:
   Trogossitidae).
AU Kolibac, Jiri (jkolibac@mzm.cz) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2928
PS 57-63
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2928.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02928p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Promanodes Kolibae, Schmied, Wappler et
   Kubisz, 2010 (Trogossitidae: Lophocaterinae: Lophocaterini), P. alleni
   sp. nov., is described from Baltic amber. Perfectly visible antennae and
   tarsi of the fossil extend morphological information about the genus and
   new character states, some of them unique among Peltinae and
   Lophocaterinae, confirm its independent status. A differential diagnosis
   of Promanodes is improved. A character analysis confirms a relation of
   Promanodes and the extant genus Promanus Sharp, 1877.
C1 Kolibac, Jiri; Moravian Museum, Department of Entomology, Hviezdoslavova
   29a, 627 00 Brno, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM jkolibac@mzm.cz

   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

   implications; new insights & new record from Baltic amber] [Tertiary / 
   / ]. 
   Promanodes alleni [Eocene /  / New species; Described from amber].

TI A new Afrotropical genus Doggerella gen. nov. of braconine wasp
   (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) with twelve new species.
AU Mahmood, Khalid
   Papp, Jeno
   Quicke, Donald L.J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2927
PS 1-37
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2927.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02927p037.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus Doggerella gen. nov. (Braconinae, Braconidae) is erected to
   include one previously described and twelve new species predominantly
   from the southern part of Africa. These species are Doggerella turneri
   sp. nov. (the type species), D. augustata sp. nov., D. longitergita sp.
   nov., D. deflexa sp. nov. and D. sulphurea sp. nov. from Republic of
   South Africa (Cape Province), D. albopilosa (Szepligeti, 1913) comb.
   nov. from Kenya, D. azhari sp. nov. and D. minuta sp. nov. from Namibia,
   D. cohaerens sp. nov. from Angola, D. landingi sp. nov. and D. shaheena
   sp. nov. from Cote d'Ivoire, D. mishkati sp. nov. from Madagascar and D.
   transversa. sp. nov. from Zimbabwe. Photomicrographs are provided to
   illustrate morphological characters of the species.

TI Description and taxonomic position of a new genus and species of
   southern African pollen beetle (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae: Meligethinae).
AU Audisio, P. (paolo.audisio@uniroma1.it) 
   Jelinek, J.
   Cline, A.R.
   Mancini, E.
   Trizzino, M.
   Cerretti, P.
   Antonini, G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2927
PS 49-56
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2927.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02927p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The pollen beetle Restiopria biondii gen. nov., sp. nov., from Western
   Cape, South Africa, is described. The taxonomic position of Restiopria
   is discussed. The new genus is not noticeably related to any other known
   Meligethine, although it exhibits a few shared characters with Pria
   Stephens 1830. Larval host plants of the single known species are male
   flowers of two species of the monocot family Restionaceae.

AN ZOOR14708061181
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of hawker dragonfly of uncertain affinities from
   the Middle Jurassic of China (Odonata: Aeshnoptera).
AU Li, Youngjun
   Nel, Andre
   Ren, Dong (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn) 
   Pang, Hong
SO Zootaxa
VL 2927
PS 57-62
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2927.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02927p062.pdf
LA English
U1 2
U2 2
AB The new aeshnopteran genus and species Sinocymatophlebiella hasticercus
   is described from the Middle Jurassic Jiulongshan Formation of Inner
   Mongolia. It shows important similarities with the Jurassic genus
   Cymatophlebiella from Karatau, suggesting they could belong to the same
   family, but the latter genus is too poorly known to accurately establish
   its affinities. The present discovery supports the evolutionary scenario
   of a Jurassic rapid and massive diversification of the Aeshnoptera,
   followed by important extinctions during the Late Mesozoic.
C1 Ren, Dong; College of Life Sciences, Capital Normal University, Beijing
   100037, China, China.
EM rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn
RI Pang, Hong/J-8710-2014
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Sinocymatophlebiella hasticercus [Nei Mongol /  / new species] [Jurassic
   /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Odonata
OR Sinocymatophlebiella (Odonata): [Gen nov, Of clade (higher taxon)
   Aeshnoptera, family Incertae sedis, Type species Sinocymatophlebiella
   hasticercus, p. 58, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Sinocymatophlebiella hasticercus (Odonata): [Sp nov, Nei Mongol,

DT Article
TI A taxonomic revision of the Stictopterinae (Lepidoptera, Noctuoidea,
   Noctuidae) in China.
AU Qi, Feng
   Wang, Ke
   Xue, Dayong (xuedy@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Yang, Ding
SO Zootaxa
VL 2926
PS 1-45
PD 22 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2926.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02926p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Stictopterinae from China are revised. Seven genera and forty
   species are reported from China. Five new species (Lophoptera hamata sp.
   nov., Lophoptera solealis sp. nov., Lophoptera acutiprocessa sp. nov.,
   Lophoptera purpurfera sp. nov. and Lophoptera trigonoprocessa sp. nov.)
   are described. One genus and ten species are recorded from China for the
   first time. Nine misidentifications in Chen (1982b, 1991, 1999) are
   revised. The male genitalia of Lophoptera obliquilinea Prout, 1928 are
   described for the frist time. Descriptions for the subfamily, all
   genera, and new species in China are provided, as are keys to genera and
   species, diagnoses for all species, and illustrations of adults and
   genitalia.
C1 Xue, Dayong; Key Laboratory of Zoological Systematics and Evolution,
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101,
   China, China.

   sp. n., is described and illustrated based on the morphological and

PT J
AN ZOOR14708061029
DT Article
TI Asterocherids (Copepoda: Siphonostomatoida) associated with marine
   invertebrates in the Strait of Gibraltar.
AU Conradi, Mercedes (mconradi@us.es) 
   Bandera, Ma Eugenia
SO Zootaxa
VL 2925
PS 1-18
PD 21 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2925.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02925p018.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Six years ago, an ongoing sampling programme to seek symbiont copepods
   was initiated in the Strait of Gibraltar. Most of the copepod species
   reported in this area (48%) belonged to the families Notodelphyidae and
   Botryllophilidae and nearly 30% of them were new to science. This paper
   describes a new species of Asterocheres (Asterocheridae,
   Siphonostomatoida) and redescribes two poorly known species of this
   genus. Asterocheres tarifensis n. sp. was found living in association
   with Astroides calycularis, a coral that hosts a variety of symbiotic
   copepods. This new species differs from its congeners by the possession
   of the following combined characters: body cyclopiform, 21-segmented
   antennule in female, 2-segmented mandibular palp, siphon reaching the
   insertion of maxilliped, maxilla without aesthetasc, maxilliped
   5-segmented, armature of the antennary exopod consisting of two setae,
   inner lobe and outer lobe of maxillule each armed with four setae,
   genital area armed with two setae, fifth leg exopod with three setae,
   and caudal rami about as long as wide. Furthermore, two poorly known
   Asterocheres species are redescribed revealing some discrepancies with
   their previous descriptions. Asterocheres minutus is characterized by
   having a 21-segmented antennule, a very short oral siphon, a 1-
   segmented mandibular palp, and the two lobes of the maxillule with a
   similar length. The cladistic model of budding hypothesis is proposed
   for the origin of the two sibling Asterocheres species: A. minutus and
   A. echinicola. Asterocheres siphonatus is distinguished by a combination
   of characters that include a 21-segmented antennule, an oral siphon
   extending to the intercoxal plate of leg 4 and the 1-segmented
   mandibular palp. The controversy concerning the name of this species is
   also studied.
C1 Conradi, Mercedes; Biodiversidad y Ecologia de Invertebrados Marinos,
   Departamento de Fisiologia y Zoologia, Facultad de Biologia, Universidad
   de Sevilla, Reina Mercedes 6, 41012 - Sevilla, Spain, Spain.
EM mconradi@us.es
RI Conradi, Mercedes/L-3207-2017
OI Conradi, Mercedes/0000-0001-9458-303X
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Associations; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic

   (Echinodermata) / Systematics] [Mediterranean Sea / Spain, Tarifa /
   Echinoderm associates]. 
   Asterocheres siphonatus [Associations / Synoicum argus (Urochordata) /
   Systematics] [Mediterranean Sea / Spain, Algeciras Bay / Urochordate
   associates]. 
   Asterocheres tarifensis [Associations / Astroides calycularis (Cnidaria)
   / New associate species] [Mediterranean Sea / Spain / New species;
   cnidarian associate]. 
   Astroides calycularis [Associations / Asterocheres tarifensis
   (Crustacea) / New associate species] [Mediterranean Sea / Spain / New
   associated crustacean species]. 
   Paracentrotus lividus [Associations / Asterocheres minutus (Crustacea) /
   ] [Mediterranean Sea / Spain, Tarifa / Crustacean associates]. 
   Synoicum argus [Associations / Asterocheres siphonatus (Crustacea) / ]
   [Mediterranean Sea / Spain, Algeciras Bay / Crustacean associates].

   [Redescription, P. 11].

   Astroides calycularis (Scleractinia).

PT J
AN ZOOR14708061030
DT Article
TI Parasitism of Apteropanorpa tasmanica Carpenter (Mecoptera:
   Apteropanorpidae) by larval Leptus agrotis Southcott (Acari:
   Erythraeidae) and Willungella rufusanus sp. nov. (Acari:
   Microtrombidiidae).
AU Seeman, Owen D. (owen.seeman@qm.qld.gov.au) 
   Palmer, Christopher M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2925
PS 19-32
PD 21 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2925.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02925p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Apteropanorpidae is a family of wingless scorpionflies endemic to
   Tasmania, comprising four described species in the genus Apteropanorpa
   Carpenter. Intensive field surveys for adult Apteropanorpa conducted
   from April to May 2002 revealed the presence of ectoparasitic mites,
   parasitising many individuals of Apteropanorpa tasmanica Carpenter at
   four localities. Laboratory investigations revealed the presence of one
   species from each of the Erythraeidae and Microtrombidiidae parasitising
   adults: Leptus agrotis Southcott and Willungella rufusanus sp. nov.,
   respectively. The larvae of W. rufusanus are described. Laboratory
   investigations of attachment sites and parasite loads of male and female
   scorpionflies are described and discussed. Results show neither sex was
   parasitised more than the other, and that up to four mites parasitised
   individual scorpionflies, although most adults supported one or two
   mites. Like many other Leptus species, all L. agrotis larvae attached to
   sclerites, whereas all W. rufusanus larvae attached to membranous areas.
   Larval W. rufusanus were predominantly attached to the scorpionfly
   abdomen; however, larval L. agrotis were more evenly distributed on the
   scorpionfly body. These data are the first records of parasitism in the
   Apteropanorpidae, and the first report of parasitism of Mecoptera in
   Australia. Parasitism of A. tasmanica by W. rufusanus is the first
   record of a mecopteran as a host for larval microtrombidiine mites.
   Parasite records for the Mecoptera are summarised.
C1 Seeman, Owen D.; Queensland Museum, PO Box 3300, South Brisbane, 4101
   Queensland, Australia, Australia.
EM owen.seeman@qm.qld.gov.au
SC Parasitology; Entomology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Acari [Insect hosts / Apteropanorpidae (Mecoptera) / New record] [ /
   Mecoptera / ] [Australia /  / ] [Tasmania /  / ]. 
   Animalia [Insect hosts / Mecoptera / Summary of reported parasitism]. 
   Apteropanorpa tasmanica [Arachnid parasites / Leptus agrotis / New
   record] [ / Willungella rufusanus / New parasite species] [Tasmania /  /
   New arachnid parasite species] [ / Mt Field National Park / ]. 
   Apteropanorpidae [Arachnid parasites / Acari / New record] [Tasmania / 
   / ].

   [Tasmania /  / ]. 
   Willungella rufusanus [Insect hosts / Apteropanorpa tasmanica
   (Mecoptera) / New parasite species] [Tasmania /  / New species from
   insect host]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari, Insecta, Mecoptera
OR Animalia: [Parasite]. 
   Acari (Arachnida): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Leptus agrotis - Southcott 1993 (Acari): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Microtrombidiinae (Acari): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Willungella - Southcott 1994 (Acari): [Key to species, Larvae, p. 26]. 
   Willungella rufusanus (Acari): [Sp nov, Tasmania, Parasite of
   Apteropanorpa tasmanica (Insecta), p. 23; Parasite]. 
   Mecoptera (Insecta): [Host; New record]. 
   Apteropanorpa tasmanica (Mecoptera): [Host; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14708061032
DT Article
TI A new species of Glischropus from the Indochinese Subregion (Mammalia:
   Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae).
AU Csorba, Gabor (csorba@nhmus.hu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2925
PS 41-48
PD 21 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2925.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02925p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Within the tribe Pipistrellini, the genus Glischropus is very close to
   the genus Pipistrellus both in its external morphology and chromosomal
   features but can be unequivocally distinguished from the latter by the
   presence of thumb pads and the position of the second incisor. One of
   the two known species, G. tylopus was thought to have a wide
   distribution range from Myanmar to the Philippines, while the other, G.
   javanus is only known from Java. Recently collected Cambodian specimens
   of Glischropus are distinguished from their congeners by longer forearm
   and cranial features (the shape of the skull and the upper incisors and
   certain craniodental measurements) and are consequentially, described
   here as a new species. Based on thorough examination of the available
   museum material, it can be concluded that all specimens of G. tylopus
   previously collected in the Indochinese zoogeographic subregion are in
   fact representatives of this new species, while G. tylopus in a strict
   sense is restricted in the mainland to south of the Isthmus of Kra.
C1 Csorba, Gabor; Department of Zoology, Hungarian Natural History Museum,
   H-1088 Budapest, Baross u. 13., Hungary, Hungary.
EM csorba@nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Eurasia; Asia

   [Vietnam /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14708061033
DT Article
TI Description of a new deep-water species of Alpheus Fabricius, 1798 from
   the Gulf of Mexico (Crustacea, Decapoda, Alpheidae).
AU Anker, Arthur (arthuranker7@yahoo.com) 
   Nizinski, Martha
SO Zootaxa
VL 2925
PS 49-56
PD 21 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2925.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02925p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new deep-water species of the snapping shrimp genus Alpheus Fabricius,
   1798 is described from two offshore localities in the northern Gulf of
   Mexico, south of Louisiana. Alpheus lentiginosus n. sp. belongs to the
   A. macrocheles (Hailstone, 1835) species group and is most closely
   related to the western Atlantic A. pouang Christoffersen, 1979 and A.
   amblyonyx Chace 1972, the eastern Atlantic A. platydactylus Coutiere,
   1897 and A. macrocheles (Hailstone, 1835), and perhaps also to the
   eastern Pacific A. exilis Kim & Abele, 1988. The new species is
   associated with deep-water soft sediments adjacent to clusters of
   Lophelia pertusa (L.) (Scleractinia) or mud-covered rocks and cobble, at
   a depth range of 336[long dash]438 m, thus representing the
   deepest-known record of the Alpheidae in the Gulf of Mexico and the
   entire western Atlantic.
C1 Anker, Arthur; Instituto de Ciencias do Mar (Labomar), Universidade
   Federal do Ceara, Fortaleza, CE, Brazil, Brazil.
EM arthuranker7@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Distribution within
   habitat; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Alpheidae [Vertical distribution / New depth record / ] [Gulf of Mexico
   / USA, Louisiana / ]. 
   Alpheus lentiginosus [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Louisiana / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia
OR Alpheidae (Natantia). 
   Alpheus lentiginosus (Natantia): [Sp nov, USA, Louisiana (marine), P.
   50].

TI A new species of frogfish of the genus Histiophryne (Teleostei:
   Lophiiformes: Antennariidae) from Queensland, Australia.
AU Arnold, Rachel J. (schoenrj@uw.edu) 
   Pietsch, Theodore W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2925
PS 63-68
PD 21 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2925.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02925p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Histiophryne maggiewalker, a new species of frogfish of the teleost
   order Lophiiformes, family Antennariidae, is described from six
   specimens collected in shallow waters off Queensland, Australia. The new
   taxon differs from its congeners in having a relatively long illicium
   and esca, the latter expanded distally, more or less rectangular; and
   genetic divergence in the nuclear recombination activation gene-2 (RAG2)
   and cytochrome oxidase-I (COI) genes. Members of the new species are
   black with a reticulate patterning discernible only with aid of

TI Two new mountain lizard species of the Phymaturus genus (Squamata:

AU Avila, Luciano Javier (avila@cenpat.edu.ar)

   Morando, Mariana
SO Zootaxa
VL 2924
PS 1-21

PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2924.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02924p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of lizards of the saxicolous and viviparous genus
   Phymaturus from Patagonia are described. The new species are members of
   the Phymaturus patagonicus species group distributed only in volcanic
   plateaus and mountains of southern Argentina. Phymaturus sitesi sp. nov.
   differs from all other members of the patagonicus group in its unique
   dorsal pattern of small white spots on a light-gray to brown-gray
   background and allopatric geographical distribution. Absence of sexual
   dichromatism differentiated Phymaturus sitesi sp. nov. from P. payuniae,
   P. zapalensis, and P. delheyi n. sp., and the midbody scales count
   differentiated from the P. delheyi sp. nov. and P. nevadoi (with some
   overlap). Also Phymaturus sitesi sp. nov. presents lower count in the
   ventral scales than in P. delheyi sp. nov. Phymaturus delheyi sp. nov.
   can be distinguished from other species of the patagonicus group by
   unique dorsal pattern of medium size white spots on a dark-brown
   background and allopatric distribution. The presence of sexual
   dichromatism differentiates Phymaturus delheyi sp. nov. from P. sitesi
   sp. nov. and P. nevadoi. Scales around midbody differentiated Phymaturus
   delheyi sp. nov. from P. payuniae and P. sitesi sp. nov. Also ventral
   scale count differentiated Phymaturus delheyi sp. nov. from P. sitesi
   sp. nov. and P. nevadoi (with some overlap).

   Investigaciones Cientificas y Tecnicas (CENPAT-CONICET), Boulevard
   Almirante Brown 2915, U9120ACD, Puerto Madryn, Chubut, Argentina,
   Argentina.

TI A new species of angular-toed gecko, genus Cyrtopodion (Squamata:
   Gekkonidae), from southern Iran.
AU Ahmadzadeh, Faraham (fahmadza@uni-bonn.de) 
   Flecks, Morris
   Torki, Farhang
   Boehme, Wolfgang
SO Zootaxa
VL 2924
PS 22-32
PD 20 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2924.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02924p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of the genus Cyrtopodion from the coastal area
   of Bushehr Province in southern Iran based on morphometric and
   pholidotic data. Cyrtopodion kiabii sp. nov. belongs to the
   agamuroides-group and the key characters to distinguish this species
   from all other members of the group are the lower number of ventrals and
   the extremely slender habitus with long and delicate legs. Resulting
   from pholidosis, the observed presence of sexual dimorphism, and
   distribution we suggest a close relationship with C. gastropholis, which
   is also reviewed herein.

DT Article
TI Four new species of the interstitial family Cobanocytheridae (Crustacea:
   Ostracoda) from central Japan.
AU Higashi, Ryouichi (downtheinterstitialworld@gmail.com) 
   Tsukagoshi, Akira
SO Zootaxa
VL 2924
PS 33-56
PD 20 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2924.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02924p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four interstitial cobanocytherid species are described from central
   Japan: Cobanocythere ikeyai sp. nov., Cobanocythere lata sp. nov.,
   Paracobanocythere watanabei sp. nov. and Paracobanocythere grandis sp.
   nov. The reports of the two new Paracobanocythere species are the second
   and third for this genus since the original description of P.
   hawaiiensis Gottwald, 1983. Cobanocythere ikeyai sp. nov., and C. lata
   sp. nov., from Japan are morphologically more similar to the species of
   the "lanceolata group" by Gottwald (1983) and C. guttaeformis Gottwald,
   1983 from the Galapagos Islands, respectively, rather than to other
   Cobanocythere species from Japan. The Japanese archipelago (eastern
   Eurasian Continent) and the Galapagos Islands (north-western South
   America) are separated by about 15,000 km from each other, and have
   never been adjoined throughout geological history. This fact, and also
   the morphological similarities between Cobanocythere species from Japan
   and the Galapagos Islands, suggests that this genus may have undergone
   global dispersal at several times in the past. Conversely, the genera
   Cobanocythere and Paracobanocythere are distributed not only around
   continents and continental islands but also around oceanic islands such
   as the Hawaiian and Galapagos Islands. We conclude, therefore, that the
   cobanocytherids seem to have been able to disperse long distances across
   oceans.
C1 Higashi, Ryouichi; Department of Geosciences, Faculty of Science,
   Shizuoka University, Oya 836, Shizuoka 422-8529, Japan, Japan.
EM downtheinterstitialworld@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Cobanocythere ikeyai; Cobanocythere lata; Paracobanocythere grandis;
   Paracobanocythere watanabei [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Cobanocythere ikeyai (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 35]. 
   Cobanocythere lata (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 40]. 
   Paracobanocythere grandis (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 50]. 
   Paracobanocythere watanabei (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P.
   45].

TI Pseudochromis erdmanni, a new species of dottyback with medially placed
   palatine teeth from Indonesia (Teleostei: Perciformes: Pseudochromidae).
AU Gill, Anthony C. (gill.anthony@gmail.com) 
   Allen, Gerald R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2924
PS 57-62
PD 20 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2924.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02924p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Pseudochromis erdmanni is described from eight specimens from Halmahera,
   Ambon and the Raja Ampat Islands, Indonesia. It is also recorded from
   Lembeh Strait, Sulawesi, on the basis of photographs. Pseudochromis
   erdmanni belongs to a clade of species with medially placed palatine
   tooth patches, which also includes P. colei Herre, P. howsoni Allen, P.
   moorei Fowler, P. quinquedentatus McCulloch, P. perspicillatus Guenther
   and P. steenei Gill & Randall. Based on derived coloration characters,
   P. erdmanni is nested within this group as the sister to P. steenei.

AN ZOOR14708060757
DT Article
TI A review of the moss bug genus Xenophyes (Hemiptera: Coleorrhyncha:
   Peloridiidae) from New Zealand: systematics and biogeography.
AU Burckhardt, Daniel (daniel.burckhardt@unibas.ch) 
   Bochud, Estee
   Damgaard, Jakob
   Gibbs, George W.
   Hartung, Viktor
   Lariviere, Marie-Claude
   Wyniger, Denise
   Zuercher, Isabelle
SO Zootaxa
VL 2923
PS 1-26
PD 20 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2923.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02923p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The moss bug genus Xenophyes from New Zealand is revised. Six species
   are recognised, four of which are described as new: X. adelphus, X.
   goniomus, X. metoponcus, and X. rhachilophus. The synonymy of Xenophyes
   forsteri with X. cascus is confirmed. Illustrated descriptions and
   identification keys are provided for the adult and the last instar. The
   male aedeagus is recognised as the most important structure to diagnose
   species. Other useful morphological characters include body shape, head,
   pronotum, and tegmina expressed as length and width measurements. The
   Principal Component Analysis (PCA) shows that five species are well
   separated from each other, but X. goniomus greatly overlaps with X.
   cascus, X. kinlochensis, and X. rhachilophus. There is also broad
   morphometric overlap between North Island and South Island specimens of
   X. cascus, confirming their conspecificity. Results from a Canonical
   Variate Analysis (CVA) determined which morphometric characters are most
   suitable for use in keys and descriptions. X. cascus is the only species
   occurring on both the North and South Islands. Other species are
   restricted to the South Island.
C1 Burckhardt, Daniel; Naturhistorisches Museum, Augustinergasse 2, CH-4001
   Basel, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM daniel.burckhardt@unibas.ch
OI Lariviere, Marie-Claude/0000-0003-3416-1286
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   ]. 
   Xenophyes adelphus; Xenophyes goniomus; Xenophyes metoponcus; Xenophyes
   rhachilophus [New Zealand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Coleorrhyncha,
   Peloridioidea, Peloridiidae
OR Xenophyes - Bergroth 1924 (Peloridiidae): [Key to species, P. 6]. 
   Xenophyes adelphus - Burckhardt 2011 (Peloridiidae): [Sp nov, New
   Zealand, P. 7]. 
   Xenophyes cascus - Bergroth 1924 (Peloridiidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Xenophyes forsteri Drake & Salmon 1948, p. 1]. 
   Xenophyes forsteri - Drake & Salmon 1948 (Peloridiidae): [Junior
   synonym, Of Xenophyes cascus Bergroth 1924, p. 1]. 
   Xenophyes goniomus - Burckhardt 2011 (Peloridiidae): [Sp nov, New

   Xenophyes metoponcus - Burckhardt 2011 (Peloridiidae): [Sp nov, New
   Zealand, P. 19]. 
   Xenophyes rhachilophus - Burckhardt 2011 (Peloridiidae): [Sp nov, New

DT Article
TI Tibiodrepanus tagliaferrii - a new Afrotropical Drepanocerina species
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Oniticellini), with notes on phylogeny and
   distribution of the genus.
AU Barbero, Enrico (enrico.barbero@unito.it) 
   Palestrini, Claudia
   Roggero, Angela
SO Zootaxa
VL 2923
PS 27-47
PD 20 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2923.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02923p047.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We examined the genera Tibiodrepanus Krikken, 2009 (four Oriental and
   one Palaearctic species) and Sulcodrepanus Krikken, 2009 (one
   Afrotropical species), using type specimens and non-type specimens, in
   order to assess the systematic consistency of the two taxa. Within this
   framework, we also considered the genera Afrodrepanus Krikken, 2009 (two
   species) and Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 (two species) employing sets of
   traits from external morphology, the genitalia of both sexes and the
   epipharynx. The genus Cyptochirus Lesne, 1900 was chosen as an outgroup.
   A new species[long dash]Tibiodrepanus tagliaferrii sp. nov.[long
   dash]was described based on four females from Cameroon and Namibia. The
   phylogenetic analyses confirmed that the Tibiodrepanus and Sulcodrepanus
   species were closely related, yet it did not support the hypothesis of a
   generic or subgeneric separation of the two taxa. Hence, we establish
   Sulcodrepanus as a junior synonym of Tibiodrepanus, new synonymy. The
   genus Tibiodrepanus shows a disjunct Afrotropical-Oriental (common to
   many other Drepanocerina genera) and Southeastern Palaearctic (Hindu
   Kush, Afghanistan) distribution pattern.
C1 Barbero, Enrico; Department of Biologia Animale e dell'Uomo, via
   Accademia Albertina 13, I-10123 Torino, Italy, Italy.
EM enrico.barbero@unito.it
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Evolution; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Tibiodrepanus [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Afrotropical region /  /
   distribution] [Oriental region /  / ] [Palaearctic region /  / ]. 
   Tibiodrepanus tagliaferrii [Cameroon /  / New species] [Namibia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae
OR Copris hircus - Wiedemann 1823 (Scarabaeidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   34]. 
   Tibiodrepanus - Krikken 2009 (Scarabaeidae): [Syn nov, Sulcodrepanus
   Krikken 2009, p. 33; Key to species, P. 33]. 
   Tibiodrepanus tagliaferrii (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov, Namibia, P. 43].

AB A new empoascine genus, Membranacea Qin & Zhang, gen. n., with three new
   species (M. spinata Qin & Zhang, sp. n., M. unijugata Qin & Zhang, sp.
   n. and M. plana Qin & Zhang, sp. n.), from China are described. In
   addition, the genus Bhatasca Dworakowska, 1995 is newly recorded from
   the Chinese mainland and a new species, B. rectangulata Qin & Zhang, sp.
   n., is described. The genus Ghauriana Thapa, 1985 is reported for the
   first time from China and a new species, G. sinensis Qin & Zhang sp. n.
   is added to the Chinese typhlocybine fauna. Keys to all species in each
   genus are given. Habitus photos and illustrations of male genitalia of
   these new species are also provided.

AB Sturmius panamaensis sp. nov. from the canopies of the San Lorenzo
   Forest in Panama is described and illustrated. The new species lacks a
   pseudonychium on the ungues, has a smaller mucro than the other species
   in the genus, and females have long anal appendices. A key to identify
   the three species known in the family is provided.

TI Ablechroiulus spelaeus sp. n. and A. dudichi Andrassy, 1970 from
   Andalucia Oriental, Spain, with a discussion of the taxonomy of the
   genus Ablechroiulus Andrassy, 1966 (Nematoda, Rhabditida, Rhabditidae).
AU Abolafia, Joaquin (abolafia@ujaen.es) 
   Pena-Santiago, Reyes
SO Zootaxa
VL 2922
PS 1-14
PD 17 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2922.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02922p014.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB One new and one known (but uncommon) species of the genus Ablechroiulus
   are described and illustrated from natural areas in the Iberian
   Peninsula. Ablechroiulus spelaeus sp. n. is characterized by having body
   length 0.81.1.48 mm in females and 0.74.1.20 mm in males, lip region
   nearly continuous and 9.13 [mu]m wide, stoma 23.29 [mu]m long or 1.8.2.7
   times the lip region width, neck 166-265 [mu]m long, metacorpus well
   differentiated, oviduct with a small sac, V = 55.59, female tail (51.60
   [mu]m, c = 14.25, c' = 1.9.2.7) with two marked sections, male tail (52,
   58 [mu]m, c = 14.3, 20.7, c' = 2.0) with filiform posterior part, bursa
   leptoderan and with nine pairs of papillae (1+2/1+2+1+2), spicules 40,
   44 [mu]m long having a terminal protuberance, and gubernaculum 20, 24
   [mu]m long. Furthermore, one female of A. dudichi Andrassy, 1970 is
   described from the north of the Iberian Peninsula. Descriptions,
   measurements and illustrations are presented for the two species, and
   SEM pictures are provided for A. spelaeus sp. n. The identity of
   Ablechroiulus is discussed, including a historical outline, its
   morphological characterization, and a discussion on the status of
   several of its species. An emended diagnosis of the genus is provided as
   well as a list of its species and a key to their identification.

TI Two new chigger mites of the genus Lacertacarus (Acari: Prostigmata,
   Trombiculidae).
AU Kaluz, Stanislav (stanislav.kaluz@savba.sk) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2922
PS 15-26
PD 17 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2922.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02922p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new chigger mites, Lacertacarus graecus sp. nov. and Lacertacarus
   turcicus sp. nov. (Acari: Prostigmata, Trombiculidae) are described from
   Greece and Turkey. The mites described come from pastures and meadows in
   mountain areas of Central Greece (Pindos Mts.), Peloponez Peninsula
   (Taigetos Mts.) and Southeast Turkey, respectively. A key to species of
   Lacertacarus is provided.

DT Article
TI Holothuria (Selenkothuria) carere, a new species of sea cucumber
   (Echinodermata: Holothuroidea) from the Mexican Pacific.
AU Honey-Escandon, Magali (mbihoney@hotmail.com) 
   Solis-Marin, Francisco A.
   Laguarda-Figueras, Alfredo
SO Zootaxa
VL 2922
PS 27-33
PD 17 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2922.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02922p033.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of sea cucumber of the subgenus Selenkothuria Deichmann,
   1958 is described. Holothuria (Selenkothuria) carere n. sp. was found in
   the Mexican Pacific, from intertidal to 6 m depth. The absences of
   ossicles in the body wall, as well as in the dorsal and ventral tube
   feet make this species unique among the species of this subgenus. Smooth
   straight rods with distal perforations and projections are present only
   in the dorsal and anal papillae, papillae at the base of the tentacles
   and in the tentacles. This species is distinctive within the subgenus.
   The shape of the ossicles shows some similarities with H. (S.)
   glaberrima Selenka, 1867.
C1 Honey-Escandon, Magali; Laboratorio de Sistematica y Ecologia de
   Equinodermos, Instituto de Ciencias del Mar y Limnologa, Universidad
   Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Apdo. Post. 70-305, Mexico, D.F. 04510,
   Mexico, Mexico.
EM mbihoney@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Holothuria (Selenkothuria) carere [North Pacific / Mexico / New
   species]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Holothuroidea
OR Holothuria (Selenkothuria) carere - Honey-Escandon & Solis-Marin 2011
   (Holothuroidea): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine), P. 29].

DT Article
TI A new species and new host records of syringophilid mites (Acari:
   Syringophilidae) from passerines from Kenya.
AU Skoracki, Maciej (skoracki@amu.edu.pl) 
   Hromada, Martin
   Wamiti, Wanyoike
SO Zootaxa
VL 2922
PS 34-40
PD 17 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2922.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02922p040.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Syringophilopsis dicruri sp. nov. (Acari: Syringophilidae) ex Dicrurus
   adsimilis (Bechstein) (Passeriformes: Dicruridae) from Kenya is
   described. Five new hosts are recorded for 4 syringophilid species:
   Chlorocichla flaviventris (Smith) and Andropadus latirostris Strickland
   (Pycnonotidae) for Syringophilopsis veselovsky Skoracki et al., 2009;
   Ploceus vitellinus Vieillot (Ploceidae) for S. nitens Skoracki and
   Dabert, 2001; Acrocephalus palustris (Bechstein) (Sylviidae) for
   Neoaulonastus bisetatus (Fritsch, 1958) and Cyanomitra olivacea (Smith)
   (Nectariinidae) for Picobia oritis Skoracki et al., 2009. The
   syringophilid fauna of the Ethiopian region is summarized in table.

DT Article
TI Shallow-water species of the genus Aplidium (Ascidiacea) from Kamchatka
   and Commander Islands.
AU Sanamyan, Karen (ascidiacea@sanamyan.com) 
   Sanamyan, Nadya
SO Zootaxa
VL 2922
PS 41-50
PD 17 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2922.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02922p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Four shallow-water colonial ascidians of the genus Aplidium
   (Aplousobranhia: Polyclinidae) are identified in the material collected
   by SCUBA divers off the coast of East Kamchatka and Commander Islands.
   Three species from Kamchatka were previously known from this region but
   were wrongly identified and two of them (A. dissectum n. sp. and A.
   eborinum n. sp.) are now redescribed as new species. Aplidium
   redikorzevi nom nov. (for Amaroucium fragile Redikorzev, 1927) is
   recorded on Commander Islands first time from its original description.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Tamarixia (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) from Chile and
   Australia, established as biological control agents of invasive psyllids
   (Hemiptera: Calophyidae, Triozidae) in California.
AU Zuparko, Robert L. (rz@berkeley.edu) 
   De Queiroz, Dalva Luiz
   La Salle, John
SO Zootaxa
VL 2921
PS 13-27
PD 16 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2921.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02921p027.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Tamarixia schina Zuparko sp. nov. and T. dahlsteni Zuparko sp. nov. are
   described. Both species have become established in California following
   their introductions from Chile and Australia, respectively, for control
   of invasive psyllids. Tamarixia schina is known from Calophya schini
   (Hemiptera: Calophyidae) on Schinus molle (Anacardiaceae) and T.
   dahlsteni from Trioza eugeniae (Hemiptera: Triozidae) on Syzygium
   paniculatum (Myrtaceae). The use of Tamarixia in biological control is
   discussed, and an annotated list of world species including
   distribution, hosts, and host plants, is provided. Tetrastichus
   atamiensis Ashmead is transferred to Tamarixia as Tamarixia atamiensis
   (Ashmead) comb. n.

DT Article
TI Monitoriella Hedqvist (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Doryctinae) from Brazil,
   with descriptions of three new species.
AU Shimbori, Eduardo Mitio (shimbori@gmail.com) 
   Penteado-Dias, Angelica Maria
   Fiorelini Nunes, Juliano
SO Zootaxa
VL 2921
PS 28-38
PD 16 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2921.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02921p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Monitoriella Hedqvist is a phytophagous, gall-inducer Braconidae genus,
   known only from the New World. Its placement in a higher taxonomic level
   has been uncertain until recent phylogenetic investigations on
   cyclostome braconids, which reinforce its position in Doryctinae. Three
   new species of Monitoriella are described: M. costalimai sp. nov., M.
   spinata sp. nov., and M. ubatuba sp. nov., all from the Brazilian
   Atlantic Forest. Monitoriella anthurii is redescribed and illustrated. A
   key to all known species is provided.
C1 Shimbori, Eduardo Mitio; Universidad Federal de Sao Carlos, Departamento
   de Ecologia e Biologia Evolutiva, Rod. Washington Luis, Km 235, CEP
   13565-905, Sao Carlos, SP, Brazil, Brazil.
EM shimbori@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

   [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Monitoriella elongata [Brazil /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Ichneumonoidea, Braconidae

AB A new genus and species of blondeliine tachinid, Tetrigimyia minor gen.
   et sp. nov., is described from Japan. This is a small oviparous tachinid
   parasitic on adults and larvae of a pygmy grasshopper, Formosatettix
   larvatus (Orthoptera, Tetrigidae). A brief biological note on this
   species is added.

DT Article
TI Panorpodes kuandianensis, a new species of short-faced scorpionflies
   (Mecoptera, Panorpodidae) from Liaoning, China.
AU Zhong, Wen
   Zhang, Jun-Xia
   Hua, Bao-Zhen (huabzh@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2921
PS 47-55
PD 16 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2921.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02921p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Panorpodes kuandianensis, a new species of short-faced scorpionflies
   (family Panorpodidae), is described and illustrated from Kuandian
   County, Liaoning Province, northeastern China. It is the third species
   of Panorpodidae from China, and can be separated from its congeners by
   the following combination of characters: wings with blackish brown
   markings; vein R4+5 much shorter than half the length of R2+3; hypovalve
   expanded apically with an almost truncated apex, shorter than the stalk,
   and with more than ten black spines along the apical inner margin. A key
   to species of Panorpodes is updated to include the new species.
C1 Hua, Bao-Zhen; Key Laboratory of Plant Protection Resources and Pest
   Management, Ministry of Education, Entomological Museum, Northwest A &F
   University, Yangling, Shaanxi 712100, China, China.
EM huabzh@nwsuaf.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Panorpodes kuandianensis [Liaoning /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Mecoptera
OR Panorpodes - MacLachlan 1875 (Mecoptera): [Key to species, Males, p.

DT Article
TI The revised identity of Cyanarmostis Meyrick, 1927: transfer from
   Heliodinidae to Oecophoridae and its new synonym Beijinga Yang, 1977.
AU Sohn, Jae-Cheon (jsohn@umd.edu) 
SO Tinea
VL 21
IS 4
PS 215-218
PD 15 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Cvanarmostis Meyrick and its type species C. vectigalis
   Meyrick are proposed to be the senior synonyms of Be/jingo Yang, syn.
   nov. and its type species Beijinga utila Yang, syn. nov., based on
   examination of the type specimens. The lectotype is designated for
   Cvanarrnostis vectigatis. Erroneous description of the brachypterous
   females of C. vectigalis by Meyrick (1927) is corrected. The
   Stathmopodinae, not Heliodinidae, association of Cvanarmostis is
   suggested.
C1 Sohn, Jae-Cheon; Department of Entomology, 4112 Plant Sciences Building,
   University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland 20742, USA, USA.
EM jsohn@umd.edu

   position

   Yponomeutoidea, Heliodinidae

   1977, p. 216; Referred to, Stathmopodinae, p. 216]. 
   Cyanarmostis vectigalis - Meyrick 1927 (Heliodinidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 216; Syn nov, Beijinga utila Yang 1977, p. 216].

PT J
AN ZOOR14710074988
DT Article
TI Review of the Taiwanese species of the genus Xerodes Guenee, (1858)
   (Geometridae, Ennominae), with taxonomic notes on the congeners from
   adjacent areas.
AU Sato, Rikio
   Stuening, Dieter (d.stuening.zfmk@uni-bonn.de) 
   Fu, Chien-Ming
SO Tinea
VL 21
IS 4
PS 219-237
PD 15 June 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomic history of the genus Xerodes is explained and its key
   characters are provided. The four species occurring inTaiwan and on the
   neighbouring smaller islands are redescribed and tools for their
   identification are given. Taxonomic notes on some congeners from
   mainland China, Far East Russia and Japan are provided. Xerodes obscura
   (Warren, 1899) is revived as bona species and separated from the similar
   X. contiguaria (Leech, 1897) and X. sordidata (Inoue. 1987). The
   synonymy of X. contiguaria cathara (Wehrli, 1940) and X. nnascula
   (Bastelberger, 1911) with X. c. contiguaria is confirmed and a lectotype
   for cathara is designated. The validity of X. didrma (Wehrli, 1940) as
   bona species is reconfirmed on the basis of the type material and a
   lectotype is designated. The poorly known X. inaccepta (Prout, 1910) is
   redescribed and compared to the similar X. crenulata (Wileman, 1915).
   The occurrence of X. semilutata (Lederer, 1853) in Taiwan is discussed.
C1 Stuening, Dieter; Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig,
   Adenauerallee 160, D-53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM d.stuening.zfmk@uni-bonn.de
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Xerodes [Taiwan /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Geometroidea, Geometridae
OR Xerodes - Guenee 1858 (Geometridae). 
   Xerodes albonotaria aritai - (Inoue 1971) (Geometridae): [Redescription,
   P. 222]. 
   Xerodes contiguaria - (Leech 1897) (Geometridae): [Redescription, P.
   230; Removal from synonymy, Zethenia obscura Warren 1899, p. 234]. 
   Xerodes crenulata - (Wileman 1915) (Geometridae): [Redescription, P.
   228]. 
   Xerodes didyma - (Wehrli 1940) (Geometridae): [Status, P. 226]. 
   Xerodes obscura - (Warren 1899) (Geometridae): [Redescription, P. 234;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Zethenia, p. 234]. 
   Xerodes semilutata - (Lederer 1853) (Geometridae): [Syn nov, Numeria
   pruinosaria Bremer 1864, p. 236]. 
   Zethenia contiguaria var. cathara - Wehrli 1940 (Geometridae):
   [Lectotype designated, P. 234]. 
   Zethenia didyma - Wehrli 1940 (Geometridae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   226]. 
   Zethenia obscura - Warren 1899 (Geometridae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   235; Removal from synonymy, With Xerodes contiguaria (Leech 1897), p.
   234; Referred to, Xerodes, p. 234]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14710074988
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14709065999
DT Article
TI A new diagnosis of Schalleriella (Acari: Oribatida: Microzetidae) and a
   new species from Vietnam.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ErmilovAcari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, Alexander E.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 16
IS 2
PS 169-175
PD Jun 15 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of oribatid mite, Schalleriella vietnamica sp. nov., is
   proposed and described from dark loamy soil of a lagerstroemia forest in
   Cat Tien National Park (southern Vietnam). This represents the first
   finding of Schalleriella in the Oriental region. The genus currently
   comprises only the type species, Schalleriella grabouwensis, from which
   S. vietnamica differs by the morphology of the lamellar apices and
   rostral setae and by the presence of an interlamellar tubercle,
   longitudinal notogastral lines and areoles in the anogenital region. A
   new generic diagnosis of Schalleriella is presented.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Nizhniy Novgorod Referral Ctr Fed Serv Vet & Phyt,
   Entomol Lab, Gagarin 97, Nizhniy Novgorod, Russia, Russia.
EM ErmilovAcari@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1362-1971
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Schalleriella [Oriental region /  / New record] [Vietnam /  / ]. 
   Schalleriella vietnamica [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Schalleriella - Engelbrecht 1972 (Acari): [Emended diagnosis, P. 170;
   New record]. 
   Schalleriella vietnamica (Acari): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 170]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709065999
DA 2020-09-17

   Sulawesi, with description of one new species of the genus Monatractides
   K. Viets, 1926.
AU Pesic, Vladimir (pesic@t-com.me) 
   Smit, Harry
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 16
IS 2
PS 187-191
PD Jun 15 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Five species of the water mite family Torrenticolidae: Torrenticola
   flangia Wiles, 1997, T. longipalpis Wiles 1997, Monatractides
   parviventris (K. Viets, 1935), M. plumosa (Wiles, 1989), M. longiventris
   (K. Viets, 1939) are reported from Sulawesi, Indonesia, and one new
   Monatractides species is described: M. sulawesiensis sp. nov.

PT J
AN ZOOR14708059988
DT Article
TI Apseudomorph tanaidaceans (Crustacea: Peracarida) from mud-volcanoes in
   the Gulf of Cadiz (North-east Atlantic).
AU Blazewicz-Paszkowycz, Magdalena (magdab@biol.uni.lodz.pl) 
   Bamber, Roger N.
   Cunha, Marina R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2919
PS 1-36
PD 15 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2919.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02919p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Faunal collections from mud-volcano sites in the Gulf of Cadiz, at
   depths between 355 and 3061 m, have revealed a high diversity (and in
   some cases high density) of tanaidaceans. A previous paper has described
   some of the tanaidomorph species found. Records of apseudomorph species
   from deep-sea chemosynthetic habitats are almost non-existent. The
   present study reports on seven apseudomorph species from five different
   genera from this material; two of the species, one in each of the genera
   Sphyrapus and Pseudosphyrapus are new to science, although there was
   insufficient material available to describe fully the Pseudosphyrapus
   species. Two of the other species are reported herein for only the
   second time. A neotype is erected for Apseudes setiferus Bacescu, and a
   lectotype for Sphyrapus malleolus Norman & Stebbing; these two, plus
   Atlantapseudes nigrifrons Bacescu and Fageapseudes retusifrons
   Richardson are redescribed. The habitus of Apseudes grossimanus is
   figured. None of the taxa appear to show any morphological features
   specifically adapted to the peculiar habitat around mud-volcanoes. The
   genus Collossella is relegated to the synonymy of Fageapseudes. The
   nonchemosynthetic- habitat-associated species Apseudes coriolis is moved
   to Taraxapseudes.
C1 Blazewicz-Paszkowycz, Magdalena; Department of Polar Biology and
   Oceanobiology, University of Lodz, Banacha 12/16, 90-237, Poland,
   Poland.
EM magdab@biol.uni.lodz.pl
RI Blazewicz, Magdalena/J-5175-2017; Cunha, Marina R/B-7644-2008
OI Cunha, Marina R/0000-0001-8833-6980; Blazewicz,
   Magdalena/0000-0002-4753-3424
SC Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Habitat; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Apseudomorpha [Marine habitat / Deep-sea mud-volcanoes / Biology;
   systematics] [North Atlantic / Gulf of Cadiz / ]. 
   Sphyrapus meknes [North Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Tanaidacea
OR Apseudes coriolis - Bamber 2007 (Tanaidacea): [Referred to,
   Taraxapseudes, p. 16]. 
   Apseudes setiferus - Bacescu 1981 (Tanaidacea): [Neotype designated, P.
   2; Redescription, P. 5]. 
   Apseudomorpha - Sieg 1980 (Tanaidacea). 
   Atlantapseudes nigrichela - Bacescu 1978 (Tanaidacea): [Redescription,
   P. 10]. 
   Fageapseudes - Bacescu & Gutu 1971 (Tanaidacea): [Syn nov, Collossella
   Jozwiak & Blazewicz-Paszkowycz 2007, p. 16]. 
   Fageapseudes retusifrons - (Richardson 1912) (Tanaidacea):
   [Redescription, P. 17]. 
   Sphyrapus - Norman 1882 (Tanaidacea): [Authorship, P. 22]. 
   Sphyrapus malleolus - Norman & Stebbing 1886 (Tanaidacea): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 22; Redescription, P. 24]. 
   Sphyrapus meknes (Tanaidacea): [Sp nov, North Atlantic, P. 29].

   Transferred from Apseudes, p. 16].

PT J
AN ZOOR14708059991
DT Article
TI A new frog of the genus Aromobates (Anura, Dendrobatidae) from Sierra de
   Perija, Venezuela.
AU Rojas-Runjaic, Fernando J.M. (rojas_runjaic@yahoo.com) 
   Infante-Rivero, Edwin E.
   Barrio-Amoros, Cesar L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2919
PS 37-50
PD 15 Jun 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2919.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02919p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of diurnal frog of the genus Aromobates is described from
   the Sierra de Perija in the Andes of western Venezuela. The new species
   is the first dendrobatid reported from this mountain range, though many
   other congeners are known from the Cordillera de Merida, also in the
   Venezuelan Andes. It can be readily distinguished from all congeners by
   the unique combination of the following characters: dorsal skin
   granulate, paired and protuberant dorsal digital scutes, finger I
   shorter than finger II, fringes absent on fingers I and IV, present and
   conspicuous on all toes, toe webbing basal, dorsolateral stripe present,
   oblique lateral stripe diffuse, ventrolateral stripe absent. With this
   new species the number of Aromobates species from Venezuela increases to
   13.
C1 Rojas-Runjaic, Fernando J.M.; Museo de Historia Natural La Salle,
   Apartado Postal 1930, Caracas, Venezuela, Venezuela.
EM rojas_runjaic@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Aromobates tokuko [Venezuela /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Dendrobatidae
OR Aromobates tokuko (Dendrobatidae): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 39].

AB Seven new species of the spider genus Enna O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1897
   from Central and South America are described and illustrated for the
   first time: Enna carinata sp. nov. (male, Panama), E. triste sp. nov.
   (male, Venezuela), E. caricoi sp. nov. (male, Colombia), E. venezuelana
   sp. nov. (female, Venezuela), E. silvae sp. nov. (female, Peru), E.
   frijoles sp. nov. (female, Panama) and E. zurqui sp. nov. (female, Costa
   Rica). A new record of Enna estebanensis (Simon, 1898) is reported from
   Ecuador.
